DT Article
TI New and Little-known Podoceridae (Peracarida: Amphipoda) of Southern
   Australia.
AU Hughes, L.E. (lauren.hughes@austmus.gov.au) 
SO Records of the Australian Museum
VL 64
IS 1
PS 71-120
PD 23 May 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Thirteen taxa in the family Podoceridae are documented for southern
   Australia, including five new species, three new records and five
   redescriptions. The redescription of Cyrtophium minutum Dana, 1852;
   Podocerus dentatus (Haswell, 1879); Podocerus hystrix Stebbing, 1910;
   Podocerus inconspicuus (Stebbing, 1888) and Podocerus lobatus (Haswell,
   1885) helps clarify existing knowledge of these old taxa.
C1 Hughes, L.E.; Australian Museum, 6 Coll St, Sydney, NSW 2010, Australia,
   Australia.
EM lauren.hughes@austmus.gov.au
OI Hughes, Lauren Elizabeth/0000-0002-5679-1732
SC Zoology
SN 0067-1975

   zones; Indian Ocean; Pacific Ocean

PT J
AN ZOOR14807052156
DT Article
TI Some hydrozoans (Cnidaria) from King George Island, Antarctica.
AU Galea, Horia R. (horia.galea@gmail.com) 
   Schories, Dirk
SO Zootaxa
VL 3321
PS 1-21
PD 23 May 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3321.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03321p021.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Twenty one species of shallow-water, benthic hydrozoans, belonging to
   nine families and fourteen genera, were found in a collection gathered
   from King George Island, South Shetland islands, during 2010 and 2011.
   Hydractinia angusta Hartlaub, 1904, Staurocladia charcoti (Bedot, 1908),
   Candelabrum penola (Manton, 1940), Orthopyxis norvegiae (Broch, 1948),
   and Silicularia pedunculata (Jaderholm, 1904) are redescribed.
   Additional notes are provided on Schizotricha turqueti Billard, 1906.
   Sertularella gaudichaudi (Lamouroux, 1824) is recognized as one of the
   most widely-distributed member of its genus in Antarctic waters.
   Taxonomic notes and updated synonymy are provided for some species.
C1 Galea, Horia R.; Hydrozoan Research Laboratory, 405 Chemin des Gatiers,
   83170 Tourves, France, France.
EM horia.galea@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Description; Synonymy; Marine zones
DE Hydrozoa [Antarctic Ocean / South Shetland Islands, King George Island /
   Faunal list; systematics]. 
TN Coelenterates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Cnidaria, Hydrozoa, Hydroida
OR Hydrozoa (Cnidaria). 
   Candelabrum penola - (Manton 1940) (Hydroida): [Redescription, P. 6]. 
   Hydractinia angusta - Hartlaub 1904 (Hydroida): [Redescription, P. 2]. 
   Orthopyxis norvegiae - (Broch 1948) (Hydroida): [Redescription, P. 17]. 
   Schizotricha turqueti - Billard 1906 (Hydroida): [Redescription, P. 15].
   
   Sertularella gaudichaudi - (Lamouroux 1824) (Hydroida): [Syn nov,
   Sertularia picta Meyen 1834, p. 10]. 
   Silicularia pedunculata - (Jaederholm 1904) (Hydroida): [Redescription,
   P. 17]. 
   Staurocladia charcoti - (Bedot 1908) (Hydroida): [Redescription, P. 4;
   Syn nov, Eleutheria hodgsoni Browne 1910, p. 2; Syn nov, Eleutheria
   kerguelensis Gilchrist 1919, p. 4]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14807052156
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14807052159
DT Article
TI A new species of the Bokermannohyla circumdata group (Anura: Hylidae)
   from southeastern Brazil, with bioacoustic data on seven species of the
   genus.
AU De Carvalho, Thiago Ribeiro (thiago_decarvalho@yahoo.com.br) 
   Giaretta, Ariovaldo Antonio
   Magrini, Leandro
SO Zootaxa
VL 3321
PS 37-55
PD 23 May 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3321.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03321p055.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB We describe a new species of the Bokermannohyla circumdata group from
   the Estacao de Pesquisa e Desenvolvimento Ambiental Galheiro
   (EPDA-Galheiro) (19[degree]12[minute]S; 47[degree]08[minute]W),
   Municipality of Perdizes, State of Minas Gerais, a mid-altitudinal
   ([approximately equal] 850 m above sea level) riparian forest
   environment in the Cerrado of southeastern Brazil. Bokermannohyla
   napolii sp. nov. is allied to the large-sized species of the group,
   diagnosed on the basis of adult morphology/morphometrics, and mainly
   vocalizations. Adult specimens of the new species are most closely
   related to those of B. luctuosa and B. circumdata, but can be
   differentiated from the former by having distal subarticular tubercle of
   finger III bifid/divided in males, and finger IV bifid/divided in males
   and females; and from both B. luctuosa and B. circumdata by a
   distinctive advertisement call structure. We also provide bioacoustic
   data on seven other species of the genus, including previously unknown
   advertisement calls of B. circumdata and B. carvalhoi, and
   re-description of the advertisement calls of B. luctuosa, B. ibitiguara,
   B. nanuzae, B. sazimai, and B. hylax.
C1 De Carvalho, Thiago Ribeiro; Laboratorio de Taxonomia, Sistematica e
   Ecologia Comportamental de Anuros Neotropicais, Faculdade de Ciencias
   Integradas do Pontal, Universidade Federal de Uberlandia (UFU), Rua 20
   no 1.600 - Bairro Tupa, 38.304-402, Ituiutaba, MG, Brazil, Brazil.
EM thiago_decarvalho@yahoo.com.br
SC Zoology; Reproductive Biology; Behavioral Sciences
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Reproduction; Reproductive
   behaviour; Behaviour; Communication; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Bokermannohyla carvalhoi; Bokermannohyla circumdata; Bokermannohyla
   hylax; Bokermannohyla ibitiguara; Bokermannohyla luctuosa;
   Bokermannohyla nanuzae; Bokermannohyla sazimai [Courtship /
   Advertisement call / ] [Acoustic signals /  / ] [Brazil /  / ]. 
   Bokermannohyla napolii [Brazil /  / New species]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates

   Bokermannohyla hylax (Hylidae). 
   Bokermannohyla ibitiguara (Hylidae). 
   Bokermannohyla luctuosa (Hylidae). 
   Bokermannohyla nanuzae (Hylidae). 
   Bokermannohyla napolii (Hylidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 39]. 
   Bokermannohyla sazimai (Hylidae). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14807052159

PT J
AN ZOOR14809059913
DT Article
TI ADDITIONS TO LATE CRETACEOUS SHALLOW-MARINE LIMOPSID BIVALVES AND
   NEOGASTROPODS FROM CALIFORNIA.
AU Squires, Richard L. (richard.squires@csun.edu) 
SO Contributions in Science (Los Angeles)
VL 520
PS 5-14
PD May 23 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A search of collections at four museums in California revealed new
   mollusks that improve the poorly known geologic record of limopsid
   bivalves and neogastropods from shallow-marine Upper Cretaceous strata
   in California. A single specimen of the bivalve Limopsis sp. (Cenomanian
   undifferentiated) from central California is significant because it is
   the earliest record of this genus from the northeast Pacific and the
   only known Cenomanian record. The morphology and distribution of
   Limopsis silveradoensis Packard, 1922, which was previously the only
   known Cretaceous Limopsis in the study area, are better established
   because newly detected specimens have much better preservation than
   previously known ones. The geologic range of this species is extended
   downward from late Turonian to include the early Turonian, and its
   geographic distribution is extended northward from Southern California
   to northern California. It is the only known Turonian record of this
   genus. Locally abundant specimens of Limopsis demerei new species (late
   Campanian to possibly early Maastrichtian) from Southern California
   represent the first post-Turonian Limopsis recognized from the northeast
   Pacific. Two single specimens of large-sized neogastropods of latest
   Campanian to possibly early Maastrichtian age are reported from San
   Diego, in Southern California. Their familial and generic
   identifications are tentative because the specimens are not well
   preserved; nevertheless, the specimens are significant because the Late
   Cretaceous record of neogastropods is meager. One specimen is possibly
   the volutid Misricymbiola? sp., which is otherwise only known from
   similar age strata in Egypt and Tunisia. The San Diego specimen is 15.6
   cm in height (incomplete) and is the largest known gastropod from Upper
   Cretaceous strata of the northeast Pacific. The other specimen is
   possibly the turbinellid Turbinella? sp.
C1 Squires, Richard L.; Calif State Univ Northridge, Dept Geol Sci, 18111
   Nordhoff St, Northridge, CA, 91330, USA, USA.
EM richard.squires@csun.edu
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Paleontology; Marine &Freshwater Biology;
   Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0459-8113
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Taxonomy; Skeletal and
   supporting structures; Shell; Shell morphology; Ecology; Habitat; Land
   zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA; Geological time periods;
   Mesozoic
DE Gastropoda [Shell biometrics / Shell height / New record] [California /
   San Diego / ] [Cretaceous / Upper Cretaceous / ]. 
   Limopsis [Land zones / Northeast Pacific region / new record]
   [Cretaceous / Late Campanian-Early Maastrichtian / ]. 
   Limopsis demerei [California /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
   Limopsis silveradoensis [California / North, Bald Hills, Ono area / new
   record] [Cretaceous / Early Turonian / ]. 
   Limopsoidea; Neogastropoda [Fossil assemblages / Fossil assemblage
   composition / New record; systematics] [Marine habitat / Shallow-marine
   habitat / stratigraphical distribution] [California / West / ]
   [Cretaceous / Late Cretaceous / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs

   Gastropoda, Prosobranchia, Neogastropoda, Muricoidea
OR Gastropoda (Mollusca): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Limopsoidea (Arcoida): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Limopsis (Limopsoidea): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Limopsis demerei (Limopsoidea): [Sp nov, California, Cretaceous, P. 8;
   Fossil]. 
   Limopsis silveradoensis - Packard 1922 (Limopsoidea): [Redescription, P.
   7; Fossil; New record]. 
   Neogastropoda (Prosobranchia): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Caricellinae - Dall 1907 (Muricoidea): [Included taxa, P. 9]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14809059913

PT J
AN ZOOR14807052158
DT Article
TI A new genus of scolopendrid centipede (Chilopoda: Scolopendromorpha:
   Scolopendrini) from the central Australian deserts.
AU Waldock, Julianne (julianne.waldock@museum.wa.gov.au) 
   Edgecombe, Gregory D.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3321
PS 22-36
PD 23 May 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3321.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03321p036.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB The first new species of Scolopendridae discovered in Australia since
   L.E. Koch's comprehensive revision in the 1980s is named as a new
   monotypic genus of the Tribe Scolopendrini, Kanparka leki n. gen. n. sp.
   Its distribution includes the Gibson and Little Sandy Deserts in Western
   Australia and the western part of the Tanami Desert in the Northern
   Territory. The new genus is especially distinguished from other
   scolopendrines by the spinulation of its robust ultimate legs,
   particular the presence of spines on the femur and tibia in addition to
   the predominantly irregularly scattered spines on the prefemur.
   Cladistic analysis based on morphological characters resolves Kanparka
   in a clade with Scolopendra, Arthrorhabdus, Akymnopellis and
   Hemiscolopendra, within which Scolopendra is non-monophyletic.
C1 Waldock, Julianne; Department of Terrestrial Zoology, Western Australian
   Museum, Locked Bag 49, Welshpool, WA 6986, Australia, Australia.
EM julianne.waldock@museum.wa.gov.au
OI Edgecombe, Gregory/0000-0002-9591-8011
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Evolution; Land zones; Australasian
   region; Australasia; Australia
DE Kanparka leki [Northern Territory /  / New species] [Western Australia /
    / ]. 
   Scolopendridae [Phylogeny / Cladogram / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Invertebrates; Myriapods
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Myriapoda, Chilopoda
OR Kanparka (Chilopoda): [Gen nov, Of tribe Scolopendrini, Type species
   Kanparka leki, p. 24]. 
   Kanparka leki (Chilopoda): [Sp nov, Western Australia, P. 24]. 
   Scolopendridae (Chilopoda).

PT J
AN ZOOR14807052162
DT Article
TI A new species of Leptolalax (Anura: Megophryidae) from central Vietnam.
AU Rowley, Jodi J.L. (jodi.rowley@austmus.gov.au) 
   Hoang, Huy Duc
   Dau, Vinh Quang
   Le, Duong Thi Thuy
   Cao, Trung Tien
SO Zootaxa
VL 3321
PS 56-68
PD 23 May 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3321.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03321p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB We describe a new species of Leptolalax from central Vietnam. Leptolalax
   firthi sp. nov. is distinguished from its congeners by a combination of
   the following characters: an absence of distinct dark brown or black
   dorsolateral markings; toes with rudimentary webbing and wide lateral
   dermal fringes in males and weak or absent lateral dermal fringes in
   females; most males with wide lateral dermal fringes on Finger II;
   medium size (26.4-29.2 mm in 21 adult males, 25.7-36.9 mm in 14
   females); and near immaculate white chest and belly. The male
   advertisement call of the new species, consisting of 2-5 notes with a
   dominant frequency of 5.4-6.6 kHz (at 18.3-21.2[degree] C) is also
   unique among Leptolalax species for which calls are known. Uncorrected
   sequence divergences between L. firthi and all homologous 16S rRNA
   sequences available were >10%. At present, the new species is known from
   montane evergreen forest between ~860[long dash]1720 m elevation in Kon
   Tum and Quang Nam Provinces. The extreme sexual dimorphism observed in
   L. firthi in terms of lateral dermal fringing, a morphological character
   often used to distinguish Leptolalax species, highlights the importance
   of ensuring interspecific comparisons in the genus are performed
   separately for each sex.
C1 Rowley, Jodi J.L.; Australian Museum, 6 College St, Sydney, NSW, 2010,
   Australia, Australia.
EM jodi.rowley@austmus.gov.au
RI Rowley, Jodi J. L./F-2466-2012
OI Rowley, Jodi/0000-0002-2011-9143
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Leptolalax firthi [Vietnam /  / New species]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura,
   Pelobatidae
OR Leptolalax firthi (Pelobatidae): [Sp nov, Vietnam, P. 58]. 
DI 10.11646/zootaxa.3321.1.4
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14807052162
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR14807052147
DT Article
TI Review of the genus Scaeosopha Meyrick, 1914 (Lepidoptera,
   Cosmopterigidae, Scaeosophinae) in the world, with descriptions of
   sixteen new species.
AU Li, Houhun (lihouhun@nankai.edu.cn) 
   Zhang, Zhiwei
   Sinev, Sergey Yu.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3322
PS 1-34
PD 22 May 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3322.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03322p034.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The genus Scaeosopha Meyrick is reviewed on a worldwide basis. A total
   of 26 species are treated, which are divided into two species groups
   except S. atrinervis Meyrick, 1931, the percnaula-group and the
   mitescens-group. Sixteen new species are described: S. betrokensis Sinev
   et Li sp. nov., S. erecta Li et Zhang sp. nov., S. hongkongensis Li et
   Zhang sp. nov., S. minuta Sinev et Li sp. nov., S. nullivalvella Li et
   Zhang sp. nov., S. sabahensis Sinev et Li sp. nov., S. spinivalvata Li
   et Zhang sp. nov., S. tuberculata Li et Zhang sp. nov., S. victoriensis
   Sinev et Li sp. nov., S. convexa Li et Zhang sp. nov., S. dentivalvula
   Li et Zhang sp. nov., S. gibbosa Li et Zhang sp. nov., S. grandannulata
   Li et Zhang sp. nov., S. nigrimarginata Li et Zhang sp. nov., S.
   rarimaculata Li et Zhang sp. nov. and S. trigonia Li et Zhang sp. nov.
   One new synonym is established: Scaeosopha stagnigera Meyrick, 1932 syn.
   nov. (= Scaeosopha percnaula Meyrick, 1914), and one new combination is
   proposed: Scaeosopha triocellata (Stainton, 1859) comb. nov. The
   previously unknown females of S. chionoscia Meyrick, 1933, S. sinevi
   Ponomarenko et Park, 1997 and S. sattleri Li, 2005 are described for the
   first time. Photographs of the adults and the genitalia of the new
   species as well as several of the described species are provided, along
   with a key for the identification of the known species and two maps to
   show the distribution of these species.
C1 Li, Houhun; College of Life Sciences, Nankai University, Tianjin 300071,
   China, China.
EM lihouhun@nankai.edu.cn
RI Sinev, Sergey/G-4633-2015

PT J
AN ZOOR14807052148
DT Article
TI Dorcadion axillare Kuester, 1847 (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae):
   distribution, morphometrics, karyotype and description of a new
   subspecies from Romania.
AU Dascalu, Maria-Magdalena (dascalumm@yahoo.com) 
   Fusu, Lucian
SO Zootaxa
VL 3322
PS 35-48
PD 22 May 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3322.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03322p048.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Dorcadion axillare Kuster, 1847 is confirmed to be present in Romania
   more than one hundred years after the last published record. This
   species was mentioned in 1908 from several localities in SE Romania by
   A. L. Montandon, but this record was overlooked or misinterpreted by
   subsequent authors, the species being currently considered endemic for
   Bulgaria. Based on all published records, museum specimens and new
   collecting data, D. axillare is in fact widely distributed in Romania.
   The specimens from the northern part of the distribution area differ
   from those in Bulgaria and are considered to belong to a different
   subspecies, D. axillare moldavicum ssp. nov. The cytogenetic study has
   revealed a karyotype with 2n = 24 and this is the first comprehensive
   information on the chromosomes of the genus Dorcadion.
C1 Dascalu, Maria-Magdalena; Faculty of Biology &quot;Al. I. Cuza&quot;
   University, Bd. Carol I, Nr 11, 700506, Iasi, Romania, Romania.

TI The genus Ampittia in Africa with the description of a new species
   (Hesperiinae; Aeromachini) and three new species in the genera
   Andronymus and Chondrolepis (Hesperiinae, incertae sedis) (Lepidoptera;
   Hesperiidae).
AU Larsen, Torben B. (torbenlarsen@btinternet.com) 
   Congdon, T.C.E.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3322
PS 49-62
PD 22 May 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3322.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03322p062.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Ampittia Moore, 1882 is accepted as a valid genus occurring in
   both Africa and Asia on the basis of a number of unusual shared
   characters, a somewhat surprising result since we had expected to
   describe a new genus. The species A. kilombero sp. nov. from Tanzania is
   described as the third African member of the genus. Andronymus fontainei
   sp. nov. is described from the DRC as a probable endemic of the
   Albertine Rift. Chondrolepis ducarmei sp. nov. is a submontane species
   that is certainly endemic to the Albertine Rift. Chondrolepis uluguru
   sp. nov. is a submontane species from the Uluguru Mountains in Tanzania;
   it is yet another endemic of the Eastern Arc Mountains that are one of
   the most urgent conservation concerns in Tanzania.
C1 Larsen, Torben B.; Jacobys alle 2, Frederiksberg, DK 1806, Denmark,
   Denmark.

TI Haploops antennata, a new species from the North Atlantic Ocean
   (Crustacea: Gammaridea: Ampeliscidae) (Contribution to the knowledge of
   the Haploops genus. 7.).
AU Kaim-Malka, R.A. (richard.elkaim@orange.fr) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3320
PS 36-46
PD 22 May 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3320.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03320p046.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Haploops antennata, a new Haploops species is described based on an
   adult femelle collected in the Concarneau area (French coast, North
   Atlantic Ocean). This species is characterized by the presence of only
   one superior pair of corneal lenses, the antenna 1 longer than the
   antenna 2 and the pereopod 7 basis narrow with inner side setose. A
   comparison is done with the Haploops species known and having only one
   superior pair of corneal lenses. A key of the 20 valid species in the
   genus Haploops is given.
C1 Kaim-Malka, R.A.; Station Marine d&apos;Endoume, Rue de la Batterie des
   Lions, 13007 Marseille, France, France.

   revealed the presence of a new species of Oxypleurodon Miers, 1886

DT Article
TI Discovery and redescription of type material of Nausithoe simplex
   (Kirkpatrick, 1890), comb. nov. (Cnidaria: Scyphozoa: Coronatae:
   Nausithoidae) from the North Atlantic.
AU Morandini, Andre C. (acmorand@ib.usp.br) 
   Jarms, Gerhard
SO Zootaxa
VL 3320
PS 61-68
PD 22 May 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3320.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/f/zt03320p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB With discovery and examination of type specimens in the Natural History
   Museum, London, UK, we reassign Stephanoscyphistoma simplex
   (Kirkpatrick, 1890) to the genus Nausithoe Kolliker, 1853, as Nausithoe
   simplex, comb. nov., and designate a lectotype for the species. Use of
   morphometric measurements is considered important in coronate
   systematics, but key features also include the unique whorl of internal
   cusps and the shape of these cusps. All previous records of N. simplex
   must be re-evaluated, taking into consideration the morphology of these
   internal cusps.
C1 Morandini, Andre C.; Departamento de Zoologia, Instituto de Biociencias,
   Universidade de Sao Paulo, Rua do Matao, trav. 14, n. 101, Sao Paulo, SP
   05508-090, Brazil, Brazil.

DT Article
TI The cumacean Genus Eudorella (Crustacea: Peracarida) from Japanese
   Waters, Northwest Pacific, and E. suluensis sp. nov. from the Sulu Sea,
   Indo-West Pacific.
AU Akiyama, Tadashi (akiyama@uml.okayama-u.ac.jp) 
   Gamo, Sigeo
SO Zootaxa
VL 3319
PS 1-56
PD 22 May 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3319.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03319p056.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Cumacean crustaceans in the genus Eudorella (Leuconidae) from Japanese
   waters, in the Northwest Pacific, were examined and the following 15
   species were recognized: E. acuticaudata sp. nov.; E.aequiremis Hansen,
   1920; E. bathyalis Vassilenko&Tzareva, 2004; E. bathyhwanghaensis sp.
   nov.; E. breviflagella sp. nov.; E. dentata Lomakina, 1955; E.
   emarginata (Kroer, 1846); E. fusafusa sp. nov.; E. haradai sp. nov.; E.
   hwanghaensis Hong&Park, 1999; E. ohtai sp. nov.; E. orientalis sp. nov.;
   E. parahirsuta sp. nov.; E. ryukyuensis Akiyama&Gamo, 2005; and E.
   setoensis Akiyama&Gamo, 2006. In addition, Eudorella suluensis sp. nov.,
   was collected from the Sulu Sea, Philippines, Indo-West Pacific, 688-693
   m. These species include 2 groups on the basis of shared morphological
   characters. Eudorella bathyalis, E. breviflagella sp. nov., E. fusafusa,
   E. orientalis, and E. setoensis are characterized by a row of simple
   setae on each side of the carapace, with both E. breviflagella and E,
   setoensis also characterized by a short flagellum on antenna 2 in adult
   males. The other group consists of Eudorella hwanghaensis, E.
   bathyhwanghaensis, and E. ryukyuensis, from southern Japan, and E.
   suluensis; with E. hwanghaensis and E. bathyhwanghaensis also
   characterized by a peculiar secondary sexual character on the tip of the
   3rd pereopod in adult males.

DT Article
TI Parapercis pariomaculata (Perciformes: Pinguipedidae), a new species of
   sandperch from Lombok and Bali, Indonesia and remarks on the validity of
   P. quadrispinosa (Weber 1913).
AU Johnson, Jeffrey W. (Jeff.Johnson@qm.qld.gov.au) 
   White, William T.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3319
PS 57-68
PD 22 May 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3319.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03319p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of pinguipedid fish, Parapercis pariomaculata, is
   described from seven specimens collected from Lombok and the southeast
   coast of Bali, Indonesia. The species appears locally common, having
   also been photographed underwater in several other locations off Bali.
   It is most similar to Parapercis clathrata in morphology, colouration
   and meristic values, but is unique among the genus in having a
   combination of dorsal-fin rays IV, 21, anal-fin rays I, 17, lateral-line
   scales 57-58, vomer with 2-4 rows of robust conical teeth, palatines
   edentate, angle of subopercle produced and with small spinules, 10
   abdominal and 20 caudal vertebrae, some nape scales weakly ctenoid in
   males, pelvic fins not reaching anal-fin origin in males, and
   colouration, including two small black spots on the suborbital, one
   above the other within a triangular reddish-brown blotch, and the
   arrangement of black and white blotching and other markings on the
   caudal fin. Comparison of the mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase subunit
   1 (CO 1) genetic marker utilised in DNA barcoding produced a significant
   genetic divergence of about 12.8% between the new species and its
   closest congener. A lectotype is designated from the two syntypes of
   Parapercis quadrispinosa (Weber) which is determined to be a junior
   synonym of P. clathrata Ogilby.
C1 Johnson, Jeffrey W.; Ichthyology, Queensland Museum, PO Box 3300, South
   Brisbane, Qld 4101, Australia, Australia.
EM Jeff.Johnson@qm.qld.gov.au
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Synonymy; Marine
   zones; Indian Ocean
DE Parapercis pariomaculata [South Indian Ocean / Indonesia / New species].
   
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Perciformes, Pinguipedidae
OR Parapercis clathrata - Ogilby 1910 (Pinguipedidae): [Syn nov, Parapercis
   quadrispinosa Weber 1913, p. 59]. 
   Parapercis pariomaculata (Pinguipedidae): [Sp nov, Indonesia (marine),
   P. 61]. 
   Parapercis quadrispinosa - Weber 1913 (Pinguipedidae): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 59]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14807051899
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14807051901
DT Article
TI The Cumacean (Crustacea: Peracarida) Genus Petalosarsia
   (Pseudocumatidae) from the Pacific Ocean.
AU Akiyama, Tadashi (akiyama@uml.okayama-u.ac.jp) 
   Gerken, Sarah
SO Zootaxa
VL 3320
PS 1-35
PD 22 May 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3320.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/f/zt03320p035.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The distribution of the cumacean family Pseudocumatidae is restricted to
   the North Atlantic, Mediterranean and brackish waters of the
   Pont-Caspian region, except for three known species of the genus
   Petalosarsia. The present study describes nine species of Petalosarsia
   from Japanese waters, the Sulu Sea, the North-west Pacific, the
   Indo-West Pacific, and the Tasman Sea, Australia. The occurrence of P.
   declivis (Sars, 1865) in northern Hokkaido agrees with the reported
   circumpolar distribution of this species. Four species from the Pacific
   coast of southern Japan and the East China Sea, P. brevirostris Gamo
   1986, P. ovalis sp. nov., P. ryukyuensis sp. nov. and P. gamoi sp. nov.,
   are characterized by prominent dorsolateral carinae with teeth
   anteriorly and the basis of the 2nd maxilliped with a semicircular plate
   on the ventral surface. Nine specimens collected from the Sulu Sea
   included five species, P. brevirostris, P. gamoi, P. jonesi sp. nov. P.
   suluensis sp. nov. and P. longicauda sp. nov. The latter three species
   were characterized by no or faint dorsolateral carinae on the carapace.
   Among them, P. jonesi was similar to P. longirostris from the eastern
   tropical deep Atlantic. Petalosarsia australis sp. nov. from the Tasman
   Sea is characterized by one faint pair of dorsolateral carinae running
   for the entire length of the carapace. The species richness of
   Petalosarsia in the Sulu Sea and the Indo-West Pacific suggests a wide
   distribution of ancestors of Pseudocumatidae around the ancient Tethys
   Sea, with the Ponto-Caspian region located near the center. The habitat
   of Petalosarsia was mostly deeper than 200 m.
C1 Akiyama, Tadashi; Ushimado Marine Laboratory, Okayama University,
   Ushimado, Okayama 701-4303, Japan, Japan.
EM akiyama@uml.okayama-u.ac.jp
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Description; Taxonomy;
   Key; Ecology; Distribution within habitat; Zoogeography; Marine zones;
   Pacific Ocean
DE Petalosarsia [Vertical distribution / Depth distribution / new record;
   systematics] [Zoogeography / Biogeography / ] [Marine zones / Southern
   Hemisphere / Distribution] [Pacific Ocean /  / ]. 
   Petalosarsia australis [South Pacific / Australia / New species]. 
   Petalosarsia gamoi; Petalosarsia ryukyuensis [North Pacific / Japan /
   New species]. 
   Petalosarsia jonesi; Petalosarsia ovalis [North Pacific /  / New
   species]. 
   Petalosarsia longicauda; Petalosarsia suluensis [North Pacific /
   Philippines / New species]. 
   Pseudocumatidae [Marine zones / Southern Hemisphere / Distribution; new
   record]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca,
   Peracarida, Cumacea
OR Kerguelenica - Ledoyer 1977 (Cumacea): [Taxonomic position, P. 33]. 
   Petalosarsia - Stebbing 1893 (Cumacea): [Diagnostic characters, P. 32;
   Diagnostic characters of subordinate taxa, P. 31; Key to species, P. 34;

AN ZOOR14807051903
DT Article
TI Biodiversity assessment of the Lower Mekong Basin: A new species of
   Corvospongilla (Porifera: Spongillina: Spongillidae) from Thailand.
AU Ruengsawang, Nisit (tongkku@windowslive.com) 
   Sangpradub, Narumon
   Hanjavanit, Chutima
   Manconi, Renata
SO Zootaxa
VL 3320
PS 47-55
PD 22 May 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3320.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03320p055.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Only six species (four genera, one family) of freshwater sponges are
   known until now from Thailand. A first record of the genus
   Corvospongilla Annandale, 1911 with the description of a new species is
   here reported from the Pong River in the Lower Mekong Basin. The
   taxonomic status of Corvospongilla siamensis nov. sp. is discussed in
   comparison to the 18 species assigned to the genus. The new species is
   characterised by i) alveolate, paucispicular skeletal network with
   scanty spongin, thick ascending tracts towards the sponge surface to
   support conules; ii) skeleton of stout microspined strongyles, and
   extremely rare, abruptly pointed oxeas usually with a few tubercles,
   plus micropseudobirotules with smooth shaft; iii) gemmules belonging to
   a single gemmular morph, typically sessile; iv) gemmular cage notably
   stout, of tangentially arranged strongyles of variable length from
   tubercled to spiny; v) gemmular theca with abundant laminar compact
   spongin, lacking pneumatic layer, armed by short, tubercled to spiny
   strongyles tangentially embedded; vi) larvae armed by spiny oxeas.
   Corvospongilla siamensis nov. sp. differs from all the other known
   species of the genus in its unique combination of diagnostic traits,
   particularly a) acanthostrongyles (megascleres), b) gemmuloscleres, both
   in the cage and in the theca, as strongyles showing the tendency towards
   ring-shape and button-like shape, and c) larval spiny oxeas.
C1 Ruengsawang, Nisit; Department of Biology, Faculty of Science, Khon Kaen
   University, Khon Kaen, 40002, Thailand, Thailand.
EM tongkku@windowslive.com
RI Manconi, Renata/AAD-9292-2019
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Ecology; Community
   structure; Zoogeography; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Corvospongilla [Species diversity / Biodiversity assessment / new
   record; systematics] [Zoogeography / Biogeographical pattern / ] [ /
   Endemism / ] [Land zones /  / distribution] [Thailand / Lower Mekong
   Basin / ] [River Mekong / Thailand, Lower Mekong Basin / ]. 
   Corvospongilla siamensis [Thailand /  / New species] [River Mekong /  /
   ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Sponges
ST Animalia, Porifera, Demospongiae
OR Corvospongilla - Annandale 1911 (Demospongiae): [Emended diagnosis, P.
   49; New record]. 
   Corvospongilla siamensis - Manconi & Ruengsawang 2012 (Demospongiae):
   [Sp nov, Thailand, P. 49].

PT J
AN ZOOR14807051738
DT Article
TI Epinotia cinereana (Haworth, 1811) bona sp., a Holarctic tortricid
   distinct from E. nisella (Clerck, 1759) (Lepidoptera: Tortricidae:
   Eucosmini) as evidenced by DNA barcodes, morphology and life history.
AU Mutanen, Marko (marko.mutanen@oulu.fi) 
   Aarvik, Leif
   Landry, Jean-Francois
   Segerer, Andreas H.
   Karsholt, Ole
SO Zootaxa
VL 3318
PS 1-25
PD 21 May 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3318.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03318p025.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB DNA barcodes of European tortricid moths identified as Epinotia nisella
   (Clerck, 1759) were found to comprise two genetically distinct clusters.
   These coincided with E. nisella and E. cinereana (Haworth, 1811) (sp.
   rev.), the latter having been considered a synonym of the former for
   several decades. Comparing these DNA barcodes with those of North
   American Epinotia showed that both species are Holarctic. The North
   American Proteopteryx criddleana Kearfott, 1907 is a new junior synonym
   of E. cinereana (syn. nov.). The two species also show distinct
   differences in male and female genitalia. North American populations of
   both species show moderate differences in barcodes from their respective
   European populations but there are no morphological differences
   correlated with the intraspecific barcode clusters. Tortrix petrana
   Hubner, 1813 is considered as a junior synonym of E. cinereana (syn.
   rev.). Epinotia nisella has several synonyms reflecting its highly
   variable forewing colour pattern. We discuss its variation and the
   status of the names associated with it. The biology of both species in
   Europe and North America is summarized. Adults and genitalia are
   illustrated.
C1 Mutanen, Marko; Zoological Museum, Department of Biology, University of
   Oulu, P.O. Box 3000, Oulu 90014, Finland, Finland.
EM marko.mutanen@oulu.fi
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Biochemistry &Molecular Biology;
   Developmental Biology; Genetics &Heredity
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Type material; Synonymy; General morphology;
   Biochemistry; Life cycle and development; Genetics; Land zones
DE Epinotia cinereana; Epinotia nisella [General morphology /  / taxonomic
   implications] [Nucleic acids / DNA barcodes / ] [Life cycle / Life
   history / ] [Molecular genetics /  / ] [Land zones / Holarctic /
   distribution]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Tortricoidea, Tortricidae
OR Epinotia cinereana - (Haworth 1811) (Tortricidae): [Syn nov,
   Proteopteryx criddleana Kearfott 1907, p. 5; Syn nov, Tortrix petrana
   Hubner 1813, p. 5; Removal from synonymy, With Epinotia nisella (Clerck
   1759), p. 5]. 
   Epinotia nisella - (Clerck 1759) (Tortricidae): [Removal from synonymy,
   Epinotia cinereana (Haworth 1811), p. 5; Removal from synonymy, Tortrix
   petrana Hubner 1813, p. 6]. 
   Proteopteryx criddleana - Kearfott 1907 (Tortricidae): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 6]. 
   Tortrix petrana - Hubner 1813 (Tortricidae): [Removal from synonymy,
   With Epinotia nisella (Clerck 1759), p. 6].

DT Article
TI Two new species of freshwater amphipods (Crustacea: Gammaridae) from
   Central Asia, with comments on the unusual upper lip morphology.
AU Sidorov, Dmitry A. (sidorov@biosoil.ru) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3317
PS 1-24
PD 18 May 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3317.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03317p024.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB This paper describes two new species of the genus Gammarus Fabricius
   from the freshwaters of Central Asia: G. montaniformis sp. nov.
   (Kazakhstan, Dzungarian Alatau, Borohudzyr River) and G. alius sp. nov.
   (Kyrgyzstan, Chatyr-Kul Lake). The morphology of the mouth parts of the
   new species G. alius is characterised by a peculiar upper lip with
   "hooks" on its epistome that is discussed. The affinity of the new
   species for their congeners is discussed, emphasizing morphological and
   biogeographical relationships.
C1 Sidorov, Dmitry A.; Institute of Biology and Soil Science, Far Eastern
   Branch of the Russian Academy of Sciences, 100-let Vladivostoku Av. 159,
   Vladivostok, 690022, Russia, Russia.

DT Article
TI Descriptions of Thereza murutinga sp. nov. and Pristocnemis caipira sp.
   nov., and new records of Caelopyginae (Opiliones: Laniatores:
   Gonyleptidae).
AU Dasilva, Marcio Bernardino (1940@uol.com.br) 
   Pinto-da-Rocha, Ricardo
SO Zootaxa
VL 3317
PS 25-38
PD 18 May 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3317.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03317p038.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of Caelopyginae are described: Pristocnemis caipira sp.
   nov. from Parque Nacional da Serra da Canastra, Minas Gerais, Brazil,
   and Thereza murutinga sp. nov., from Parati, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.
   Pristocnemis caipira sp. nov. is diagnosed by shallow grooves on the
   dorsal scutum, a lower number of tarsal segments, presence of a spine on
   the anal operculum, large, pointed tubercles on the lateral margins of
   the dorsal scutum, and an absence of white patches on the dorsal scutum.
   Thereza murutinga sp. nov. is diagnosed by the combination of the
   following characters: incomplete median longitudinal groove on area III
   and absent on area II, prosoma much smaller than opisthosoma, and a
   large white patch covering the prosoma and whole areas of the
   opisthosomal scutum. A cladistic analysis including the two new species
   was performed to investigate their relationship within the subfamily. We
   obtained 927 trees of 185 steps (CI=0.4, RI=0.74), which corroborated
   the generic assignments of the new species, but infrageneric
   relationships remained unsolved. In addition, male genitalia of Ampheres
   luteus (Giltay) and genera Pristocnemis and Thereza are redescribed, new
   distribution records for Caelopyginae species are presented, and
   biogeographical implications are discussed.
C1 Dasilva, Marcio Bernardino; Departamento de Sistematica e Ecologia,
   Centro de Ciencias Exatas e da Natureza, Universidad Federal da Paraiba,
   CEP 58051-970, Joao Pessoa, PB, Brazil, Brazil.
EM 1940@uol.com.br
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   Land zones; Neotropical region; South America

   pustulatus; Thereza speciosa [Brazil /  / New record]. 
   Caelopyginae [Phylogeny /  / ] [Zoogeography /  / ] [Brazil /  / ]. 
   Pristocnemis caipira; Thereza murutinga [Brazil /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Opiliones
OR Ampheres fuscopunctatus (Opiliones): [New record].

DT Article
TI New species of Pista Malmgren, 1866 (Polychaeta: Terebellidae) from the
   Caribbean.
AU Londono-Mesa, Mario H. (mlondono@biologia.udea.edu.co) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3317
PS 39-48
PD 18 May 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3317.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03317p048.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Three new species of Pista are described. Pista vossae sp. nov., occurs
   from Florida to Jamaica and Venezuela. This species is distinguished by
   uncini having few teeth, and base shaped with a rounded anterior
   process. Pista lizae sp. nov., is present in Florida, the Gulf of Mexico
   and Panama. This species is distinguished by having a lobe on the dorsal
   edge of segment 4, eyespots, and uncini with long posterior processes on
   the anteriormost three uncinigers only. Finally, Pista hataam sp. nov.,
   from Yucatan Basin, is distinguished by having two lobes on the dorsal
   edge of segment 4, separated by a smooth swollen membrane, and all
   thoracic uncini with long posterior processes. Thus, the number of
   species of Pista for the region is doubled to six. A taxonomic key for
   Caribbean species is provided.
C1 Londono-Mesa, Mario H.; Instituto de Biologia, Grup LimnoBasE y
   Biotamar, Universidad de Antioquia, Calle 67 No. 53-108, Medellin
   (Antioquia), CP 5001000, Colombia, Colombia.
EM mlondono@biologia.udea.edu.co
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   Atlantic Ocean; North Atlantic

DT Article
TI Parambassis bistigmata, a new species of glassperch from north-eastern
   India (Teleostei: Ambassidae).
AU Geetakumari, Khangjrakpam (geetameme@gmail.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3317
PS 59-64
PD 18 May 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3317.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03317p064.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Parambassis bistigmata, a new species of glassperch from northeast
   India, is distinguished from its congeners by the combination of the
   following characters: two distinct black spots on either side of the
   anal-fin origin connected by a narrow black curved line; 13-14 gill
   rakers on the first gill arch; 65-67 scales in lateral series; a well
   developed pre-orbital edge with prominent, acute spines, almost covering
   the upper lip; dorsal and ventral sides of caudal peduncle with a
   longitudinal black stripe; and the presence of a faint, vertically
   elongated humeral spot.
C1 Geetakumari, Khangjrakpam; ICAR, Research Complex for NEH Region Manipur
   Centre, Lamphelpat Imphal-795004, Manipur, India, India.

TI On species related to Elachista hedemanni Rebel (Lepidoptera:
   Elachistidae: Elachistinae), with descriptions of three new Palearctic
   species.
AU Kaila, Lauri (lauri.kaila@helsinki.fi) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3316
PS 28-39
PD 17 May 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3316.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03316p039.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The taxonomy of Elachista (Aphelosetia) hedemanni Rebel, 1899, and its
   relatives is clarified. The following species are described as new:
   Elachista gilvula sp. n. from Russia: Tuva with additional record from
   Kazakhstan, Elachista galbina sp. n. from Kazakhstan and Elachista
   cirrhoplica sp. n. from Spain. The systematics of an assemblage of
   species related to Elachista (Aphelosetia) pollinariella Zeller is
   discussed, and characters possibly enabling the further division of the
   subgenus Aphelosetia to more manageable units are suggested.

TI Australodindymus nigroruber gen. et sp. nov. from Western Australia
   (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Pyrrhocoridae).
AU Stehlik, Jaroslav L.
   Jindra, Zdenek
SO Zootaxa
VL 3316
PS 57-62
PD 17 May 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3316.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03316p062.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus and species, Australodindymus nigroruber gen. et sp. nov.,
   is described from the Pilbara region of Western Australia based on male,
   female and 5th instar nymph. This endemic genus is related to the
   cosmopolitan genus, Dindymus Stal, 1861, but differs markedly in
   structure of both male and female genitalia, and is the first member of
   the Pyrrhocoridae recorded from Western Australia.

TI A new species of leaf-litter inhabiting Georissus from Borneo
   (Coleoptera: Hydrophiloidea: Georissidae).
AU Fikacek, Martin (mfikacek@gmail.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3316
PS 63-68
PD 17 May 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3316.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03316p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Georissus (Neogeorissus) smetanai sp. nov. is described from Mt.
   Kinabalu National Park, Sabah, Malaysia. Long series of this species has
   been sifted from cloud forest leaf litter in contrast to most species of
   the genus, which are most frequently collected in riparian zones. The
   species is compared with G. lateralis Deleve, 1967 and G. inflatus
   Deleve, 1972, which were collected under similar circumstances and the
   leaf-litter habits of the three species are briefly discussed.

PT J
AN ZOOR14808056875
DT Article
TI A Revision of the Neotropical Goblin Spider Genus Neoxyphinus Biraben,
   1953 (Araneae, Oonopidae).
AU Abrahim, Naiara
   Brescovit, Antonio D.
   Rheims, Cristina A.
   Santos, Adalberto J.
   Ott, Ricardo
   Bonaldo, Alexandre B.
SO American Museum Novitates
VL 3743
PS 1-75
PD May 16 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The Neotropical spider genus Neoxyphinus Biraben, 1953, is revised,
   comprising 10 species found from the West Indies to northern Argentina.
   The genus is characterized by a unique combination of characters, which
   include the presence of a set of low tubercles or large spikes on the
   posterior surface of carapace; male endites with an apical, retrolateral
   excavation bearing a subapical toothlike apophysis; palpal bulb strongly
   inflated; embolus compact, S-shaped, with large, round ejaculatory
   opening; epigynal atrium large, with angular lateral corners. The large,
   round ejaculatory duct may be a synapomorphy of the genus. The genus
   Hawkeswoodoonops Makhan and Ezzatpanah, 2011, is synonymized with
   Neoxyphinus and the two species included in that genus are considered as
   nomina dubia. The monotypic genus Decuana Dumitrescu and Georgescu,
   1987, is also synonymized with Neoxyphinus and its type species, D.
   hispida Dumitrescu and Georgescu, 1987, is transferred to the genus and
   redescribed. Confirming a hypothesis raised in the literature, Dysderina
   termitophila Bristowe, 1938, is transferred to Neoxyphinus and
   recognized as the senior synonym of the type species N. ogloblini
   Biraben, 1953. Two other species are transferred from Dysderina to
   Neoxyphinus: D. keyserlingi Simon, 1907, here recognized as the senior
   synonym of D. Rugosa Bristowe, 1938, and D. furtiva Chickering, 1968, of
   which the male is described for the first time. In addition to the
   redescription of N. termitophilus, n. comb., N. hispidus, n. comb., N.
   xyphinoides (Chamberlin and Ivie, 1942), N. keyserlingi, n. comb., and
   N. furtivus, n. comb., five new species are described: N. petrogoblin
   Abrahim and Ott, from the Amazon basin in Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, and
   Peru; N. gregoblin Abrahim and Santos, from Venezuela; N. axe Abrahim
   and Brescovit, from Bahia, Brazil; N. boibumba Abrahim and Rheims, from
   Para, Brazil; and N. barreirosi Abrahim and Bonaldo, from Brazil,
   Colombia, Guyana, and Venezuela. With the exception of N. boibumba,
   known only from males, all new species are described from both sexes.
C1 Abrahim, Naiara; Museu Paraense Emilio Goeldi, Lab Aracnol, Campus
   Pesquisa,Av Perimetral 1901, Belem, PA, BR-66040170 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
RI Bonaldo, Alexandre Bragio/C-6622-2011; BRESCOVIT, ANTONIO/Y-1169-2019;
   Brescovit, Antonio/B-5215-2016; Santos, Adalberto J/H-8349-2012; Rheims,
   Cristina/L-6117-2014
OI Bonaldo, Alexandre Bragio/0000-0002-8216-5110; Brescovit,
   Antonio/0000-0002-1511-5324; Santos, Adalberto J/0000-0002-0010-346X;
   Rheims, Cristina/0000-0003-4418-0552
SC Zoology
SN 0003-0082; 1937-352X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Combination; Synonymy;
   Available name; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; South America
DE Neoxyphinus axe; Neoxyphinus boibumba [Brazil /  / New species]. 
   Neoxyphinus barreirosi [Brazil /  / New species] [Colombia /  / ]

TI Description of four new species Limnadopsis from Australia (Crustacea:
   Branchiopoda: Spinicaudata).
AU Schwentner, Martin (martin.schwentner@uni-rostock.de) 
   Timms, Brian V.
   Richter, Stefan
SO Zootaxa
VL 3315
PS 42-64
PD 16 May 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3315.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03315p064.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Four new species of Limnadopsis, L. bloodwoodensis sp. nov., L.
   paratatei sp. nov., L. brevirostris sp. nov. and L. centralensis sp.
   nov., are described for Australia. Three of these were delineated in an
   earlier study based on an integrative taxonomic approach. The fourth (L.
   centralensis sp. nov.) was not part of that study but can be
   distinguished from all other Limnadopsis morphologically. The
   morphological variation in L. tatei is described here in detail as L.
   paratatei sp. nov. and L. tatei closely resemble each other and have in
   earlier studies been grouped together as L. tatei.

PT J
AN ZOOR14807051277
DT Article
TI Description of a rheophilic Tilapia species Smith, 1840 (Teleostei:
   Cichlidae) from Guinea with comments on Tilapia rheophila Daget, 1962.
AU Dunz, Andreas R. (dunz@zsm.mwn.de) 
   Schliewen, Ulrich K.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3314
PS 17-30
PD 16 May 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3314.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03314p030.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Tilapia konkourensis, new species, is described on the basis of three
   specimens from the upper Konkoure River and its tributary Kakrima. The
   rheophilic species differs from all other Tilapia sensu lato except T.
   fusiforme Dunz&Schliewen, 2010 in a shallower body 30.0-31.5% vs.
   32.9-52.5% SL and from T. fusiforme in having eight instead of nine to
   twelve lower lateral-line scales. It is most similar to Tilapia
   rheophila Daget, 1962, type species of the monotypic subgenus Tilapia
   (Dagetia) Thys van den Audenaerde, 1969. An evaluation of the putative
   autapomorphies diagnosing Dagetia revealed that all are shared with
   members of the subgenus Coptodon Gervais, 1853 sensu Thys van den
   Audenaerde, 1969; hence, Tilapia (Dagetia) is placed in the synonymy of
   Tilapia (Coptodon).
C1 Dunz, Andreas R.; Department of Ichthyology, Bavarian State College of
   Zoology, Muenchhausenstr. 21, 81247 Muenchen, Germany, Germany.
EM dunz@zsm.mwn.de
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Synonymy; Land zones; Afrotropical
   region; Africa
DE Tilapia konkourensis [Guinea /  / New species]. 
   Tilapia rheophila [Guinea /  / Distribution; systematics]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Perciformes, Cichlidae

PT J
AN ZOOR14807051281
DT Article
TI Taxonomy and distribution of the genus Eurydice Leach, 1815 (Crustacea,
   Isopoda, Cirolanidae) from the Arabian region, including three new
   species.
AU Jones, David Alan (wendavjones@terra.es) 
   Nithyanandan, Manickam
SO Zootaxa
VL 3314
PS 45-57
PD 16 May 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3314.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03314p057.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Three new subtidal species of Eurydice are described, i.e. Eurydice
   tridentata sp. nov. and Eurydice marisrubri sp. nov. from the Red Sea,
   and Eurydice marzouqui sp. nov. from the Arabian/Persian Gulf. These
   species can be separated from all other Eurydice in the Arabian region
   by the absence of robust setae on the posterior margin of the
   pleotelson. E. marisrubri has a truncate posterior margin bearing 5
   apical teeth, E. marzouqui has a rounded pleotelson posterior margin
   with 6 apical teeth and in E. tridentata the posterior margin is
   truncate, bearing 7 apical teeth, the central 3 prominent. Additional
   information is provided for two previously described species: E.
   peraticis Jones, 1974 and E. arabica Jones, 1974. Previous records of E.
   inermis are attributed to E. tridentata and E. inermis is excluded from
   the region. A key is provided to separate all the Eurydice species
   likely to be found in the Arabian region. The distribution of all the
   Arabian Eurydice is described, and morphology is discussed in relation
   to habitat.
C1 Jones, David Alan; Personal Postal, Box Number 443, Ctra. Cabo La Nao
   (Pla) 124-6, 03730, Javea, Alicante, Spain, Spain.
EM wendavjones@terra.es
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Marine zones; Indian
   Ocean; North Indian Ocean
DE Eurydice [Persian Gulf /  / Key to species] [ /  / Distribution;
   systematics] [Red Sea /  / ] [ /  / ]. 
   Eurydice arabica [Persian Gulf /  / New record]. 
   Eurydice marisrubri; Eurydice tridentata [Red Sea / Israel / New
   species]. 
   Eurydice marzouqui [Persian Gulf / Kuwait / New species] [ / Saudi
   Arabia / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca,
   Peracarida, Isopoda
OR Eurydice - Leach 1815 (Isopoda): [Key to species, Persian Gulf & Red
   Sea, P. 47]. 
   Eurydice arabica (Isopoda): [New record]. 
   Eurydice marisrubri (Isopoda): [Sp nov, Israel (marine), P. 51]. 
   Eurydice marzouqui (Isopoda): [Sp nov, Saudi Arabia (marine), P. 47]. 
   Eurydice tridentata (Isopoda): [Sp nov, Israel (marine), P. 48]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14807051281

PT J
AN ZOOR14807051282
DT Article
TI A new species of Halichondriidae, Topsentia vaceleti n. sp.
   (Halichondrida, Demospongiae, Porifera), collected from coralligenous
   bottoms of the Aegean Sea.
AU Kefalas, Efthimios (cathario@biol.uoa.gr) 
   Castritsi-Catharios, Jeanne
SO Zootaxa
VL 3314
PS 58-68
PD 16 May 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3314.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03314p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species, Topsentia vaceleti n. sp., was collected from 70m depth,
   on a coralligenous bed of the Aegean Sea by trawl (sponge fishing gear
   "gagava"). The specimen is spherical, 8 cm in diameter, with deep
   surface grooves. It has a totally disordered choanosome and a tangential
   ectosomal skeleton, typical of Topsentia, but exhibits a different type
   of spiculation. This species differs from the other members of the genus
   by possessing both principal oxeas and secondary oxeas, the latter much
   longer but thinner, bent and in some cases flexuous or twisted. This is
   the fourth species of Topsent ia Berg, 1899 reported from the
   Mediterranean Sea.
C1 Kefalas, Efthimios; University of Thessaly, School of Agricultural
   Sciences, Department of Ichthyology and Aquatic Environment, Fyotoko
   Street, N. Ionia, Magnesia, 38446, Greece, Greece.
EM cathario@biol.uoa.gr
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Marine zones; Atlantic
   Ocean; North Atlantic
DE Topsentia vaceleti [Mediterranean Sea / Greece / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Sponges
ST Animalia, Porifera, Demospongiae
OR Topsentia - Berg 1899 (Demospongiae): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, P. 65]. 
   Topsentia vaceleti (Demospongiae): [Sp nov, Greece (marine), P. 59].

AN ZOOR14807051275
DT Article
TI Description of two new species of sea bass (Teleostei: Latidae: Lates)
   from Myanmar and Sri Lanka.
AU Pethiyagoda, Rohan (rohan.pethiyagoda@austmus.gov.au) 
   Gill, Anthony C.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3314
PS 1-16
PD 16 May 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3314.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/f/zt03314p016.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Two new species of Lates Cuvier are described. Lates lakdiva, new
   species, from western Sri Lanka, differs from its Indo-Pacific congeners
   by its lesser body depth, 26.6-27.6% SL; 5 rows of scales in transverse
   line between base of third dorsal- fin spine and lateral line; 31-34
   serrae on the posterior edge of the preoperculum; third anal-fin spine
   longer than second; 47-52 lateral-line scales on body; and greatest
   depth of maxilla less than eye diameter. Lates uwisara, new species,
   from eastern Myanmar, is distinguished by possessing 7 scales in
   transverse line between base of third dorsal-fin spine and lateral line;
   eye diameter 4.4-4.7% SL; body depth 28.4-34.5% SL; and third anal-fin
   spine shorter than the second. Despite substantial genetic variation, L.
   calcarifer sensu lato is widely distributed, from tropical Australia
   through Indonesia, Singapore and Thailand, westwards to at least the
   west coast of India. Caution is urged in translocating Lates in the
   Indo-Pacific region as other yet unrecognized species likely exist. The
   status of the type specimens of L. calcarifer is discussed, and a common
   lectotype designated for L. heptadactylus and L. nobilis. While Lates
   vacti (type locality Bengal) may be a valid species, L. cavifrons and L.
   darwiniensis are considered synonyms of L. calcarifer. Plectopomus
   Goldfuss and Ptertopomus Goldfuss are shown to be incorrect subsequent
   spellings of Plectropomus Oken.
C1 Pethiyagoda, Rohan; Australian Museum, 6 College Street, Sydney, NSW
   2010, Australia, Australia.
EM rohan.pethiyagoda@austmus.gov.au
OI Gill, Anthony/0000-0002-8990-3657
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Marine zones; Indian
   Ocean; North Indian Ocean
DE Lates [Indian Ocean / Indo-Pacific / Distribution; systematics] [Pacific
   Ocean /  / ]. 
   Lates lakdiva [North Indian Ocean / Sri Lanka / New species]. 
   Lates uwisara [Bay of Bengal / Myanmar / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Beryciformes, Holocentridae, Perciformes, Centropomidae, Serranidae
OR Holocentrus calcarifer - Bloch 1790 (Holocentridae): [Type material,
   Type status, p. 9]. 
   Holocentrus heptadactylus - Lacepede 1802 (Holocentridae): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 10]. 
   Plectopomus - Goldfuss 1820 (Perciformes): [Spelling, P. 11]. 
   Lates (Centropomidae). 
   Lates calcarifer - (Lacepede 1802) (Centropomidae): [Synonymy, P. 10]. 
   Lates lakdiva (Centropomidae): [Sp nov, Sri Lanka (marine), P. 4]. 
   Lates nobilis - Cuvier in Cuvier & Valenciennes 1828 (Centropomidae):
   [Lectotype designated, P. 10]. 
   Lates uwisara (Centropomidae): [Sp nov, Myanmar (marine), P. 6]. 
   Ptertopomus - Goldfuss 1820 (Centropomidae): [Spelling, P. 11]. 
   Plectropomus - Oken 1817 (Serranidae): [Spelling, P. 11].

AN ZOOR14807051278
DT Article
TI A new genus of Cranaidae from Ecuador (Opiliones: Laniatores).
AU Kury, Adriano B. (adiranok@gmail.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3314
PS 31-44
PD 16 May 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3314.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03314p044.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The new genus Zannicranaus is described from the Andes in central
   Ecuador based on two new species. It is characterized by a guitar-shaped
   body, short sturdy pedipalpus, unique strong spiniform process in the
   frontal hump, sexually dimorphic basichelicerite (very strong in male),
   an erect spine on the cheliceral bulla and paired ventral armature on
   male coxa IV. Zannicranaus monoclonius sp. nov., a species profusely
   colored in red, yellow and green, is described from Chimborazo Province
   (Sibambe). Zannicranaus morlacus sp. nov., a dull-brown colored species,
   is the first reported harvestman from Azuay Province (Molleturo). The
   stylar caps, a novel structure, is described in the male genitalia of
   Cranaidae.
C1 Kury, Adriano B.; Departamento de Invertebrados, Museu Nacional/UFRJ,
   Quinta da Boa Vista, Sao Cristovao, 20.940-040, Rio de Janeiro, RJ,
   Brazil, Brazil.
EM adiranok@gmail.com
RI Kury, Adriano Brilhante/C-3202-2009
OI Kury, Adriano Brilhante/0000-0002-8334-6204
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Opiliones [Ecuador / Azuay / New record].

   species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Opiliones
OR Opiliones (Arachnida): [New record].

TI Biodiversity of the Aleocharinae of China: Lomechusini and Thamiaraeini
   (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae).

   (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae).

LA French
U1 0
U2 1
AB Description of 21 new species of the tribes Lomechusini and Thamiaraeini
   belonging to the genera Orphnebius (O. uncinatus n. sp.), Tetrabothrus
   (T chinensis n. sp.), Drusilla (D. damingensis n. sp., D.
   cenwanglaomontis n. sp., D. gilva n. sp., D. sinicola n. sp.), Zyras (Z.
   qingchengensis n. sp., Z. sichuanorum n. sp., Z. yongshengensis n. sp.,
   Z. diaoluomontis n. sp., Z. fellowesi n. sp.), Pedinopleurus (P.
   jiuwanmontis n. sp.), Eutaenoglossa (E. schuelkei n. sp.), Platorischna
   (P. sinensis n. sp., P. sichuanensis n. sp.), Lasiokogphina n. gen. (L.
   sinica n. sp.), Medeterusa (M. chinensis n. sp.), Mimacrotona (M.
   chinensis n. sp.), Mimoxypoda (M. sinica n. sp., Al. sinorum n. sp.),
   Litoglossa (L. chinensis n. sp.). Each new species is illustrated and
   compared with similar species. Additional distributional data are
   reported for 14 species. The new genus Lasiokoryphina is similar to
   Platorischna. Drusilla hanoiensis PAgNIK, 2000 is placed in synonymy
   with Zyras rufithorax CAMERON, 1930. New combination is proposed for 1
   species.

TI Biodiversity of the Aleocharinae of China: Hygronomini and Oxypodini
   (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae).
FT Biodiversita delle Aleocharinae della Cina: Hygronomini e Oxypodini
   (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae).
AU Pace, Roberto (pace.ent@tiscali.it)

LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB Description of 37 new species of the tribes Hygronomini and Oxypodini
   belonging to the genera Hygrochara (H. sinica n. sp.), Apimela (A.
   jaegeri n. sp., A. sinofluminis n. sp., A. jiajinensis n. sp., A.
   glarearzim n. sp., A. tibetana n. sp.), Drepasiagonusa n. gen. (D.
   smetanai n. sp.), Sinofeluva n. gen. (S. qinlingmantis n. sp.),
   Himalkompsusa (H. sinica n. sp.), Blepharhymenus (B. smetanai n. sp., B.
   dabensis n. sp.), Ocalea (O. lobifera n. sp., O. plicasentiens n. sp.,
   O. magna n. sp., O. intermedia n. sp., O. ming n. sp., O. shaanxiensis
   n. sp., O. erlangensis n. sp.), Porocallus (P. sinensis n. sp.), Irmaria
   (I. chinensis n. sp., I. zerchei n. sp.), Ogusa (O. tibetana n. sp.),
   Tilchoglossina (T. decoripennis n. sp., T nona n. sp., T tibetana n.
   sp., T daxuensis n. sp., T xuemontis n. sp., T pianpaoensis n. sp., T
   taibaiensis n. sp., T tronqueti n. sp., T glaciei n. sp., T
   sinuatolatera n. sp., T zhongdianensis n. sp., T. yunnanensis n. sp., T
   erlangensis n. sp., T emeimontis n. sp., T erdaoensis n. sp.). The new
   genus Drepasiagonusa is similar to Beijingusa and the new genus
   Sinofeluva it is similar to Feluva. Every new species is illustrated and
   compared with similar species. The genera Hygrochara, Achtherampla,
   Himalkompsusa and Irmaria are new for China. The genus Pltaysmarthrusa
   PACE, 1999 is junior synonym of Porocallus SHARP, 1888, the genus
   Ptochusa PACE, 2006 is junior synonym of Irmaria CAMERON 1925. Nine new
   combinations are proposed. Trichoglossina anetanaiana is new name for
   Trichoglossina smetanai PACE, 1999. Additional distributional records
   are reported for 6 species.

PT J

DT Article
TI Contribution to the knowledge of the Tineidae of Nepal and neighbouring
   regions (Lepidoptera: Tineidae).
FT Beitrag zur Kenntnis der Tineiden von Nepal und benachbarter Gebiete
   (Lepidoptera: Tineidae).
AU Gaedike, Reinhard (tinagma@msn.com) 
SO Beitraege zur Entomologie
VL 62
IS 1
PS 165-206
PD May 15 2012
PY 2012
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB The hitherto undetermined Tineidae from the Nepal expeditions of the
   Zoologische Staatssammlung Munchen were studied, together with material
   from the museums of Paris, Helsinki, Copenhagen, and some specimens from
   India and Pakistan from the collections of GEORG DERRA and ERNST
   ARENBERGER. The following new species are described: Rhodobates dierli
   sp. n.; R. pusillus sp. n.; Infurcitinea fibigeri sp. n.; Pachyarthra
   nepalica sp. n.; P. dierli sp. n.; P. aurata sp. n.; Edosa Aculeata sp.
   n.; E. parva sp. n.; E. magna sp. n.; E. fastigata sp. n.; E. rapticok
   sp. n.; E. clavifera sp. n.; E. dierli sp. n.; E. hackeri sp. n.; E.
   spinosa sp. n.; E. fibigeri sp. n.; Tinea nepalica sp. n.; Crypsithyris
   arenbergerarum sp. n.; C. nepalicola sp. n.; C. corn uta sp. n. Female
   genitalia of the following three species are described for the first
   time: Edosa opsigona (MEYRicic, 1911), E. nestoria (MEraicx, 1910), and
   1?erissomastix (Aphrodoxa) peterseni (AmsEL, 1959). Edosa subochraceelb
   (WALSINGHAM, 1886); E. mphnodes (MEYRicx, 1911); Perissomastix afghana
   (PETERSEN, 1959); Monopis longella (WALKER, 1863), and Gerontha
   dracuncula MEYRICK, 1928 are recorded as new for the fauna of Nepal,
   Edosa synaema (MEYRicic, 1905) and Perissomastix afghana (PETERSEN,
   1959) for Pakistan, and Perissomastix (Aphrodoxa) peterseni (AmsEL,
   1959) for India. Adults and genitalia of all new species are figured.
C1 Gaedike, Reinhard; Florusstr 5, Bonn, D-53225, Germany, Germany.
EM tinagma@msn.com
SC Zoology
SN 0005-805X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; India

   clavifera; Edosa dierli; Edosa fibigeri; Edosa parva; Edosa rapticola;
   Infurcitinea fibigeri; Pachyarthra aurata; Pachyarthra dierli;
   Pachyarthra nepalica; Rhodobates dierli; Rhodobates pusillus [Nepal /  /
   New species].

   [Pakistan /  / ].

   Gerontha dracuncula; Monopis longella [Nepal /  / New record].

   ].

   systematics] [Nepal /  / ].

PT J
AN ZOOR14810069103
DT Article
TI [Revision of the genus Agachila DRAICE & GOMEZ-MENOR, 1954 (Hemiptera:
   Heteroptera: Tingidae).]
FT Revision der Gattung Agachila DRAICE & GOMEZ-MENOR, 1954 (Hemiptera:
   Heteroptera: Tingidae).
AU Goellner-Scheiding, Ursula
SO Beitraege zur Entomologie
VL 62
IS 1
PS 235-246
PD May 15 2012
PY 2012
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Agachila, family Tingidae, is distributed in tropical Africa
   only. The genus is revised here. Three species Agachila barbarae, A.
   constanti and A. heinrichae are described as new. The species Agachila
   biafrana DRAKE&GOMEZ-MENOR, 1954, is a synonym of Agachila motoensis
   (SCUOUTEDEN, 1953). The genus Agachila and its altogether nine species
   are characterised. Most of the species live in Central-Africa, only one
   species in the Republic of South Africa. An identification key and a
   list of the species is given.
C1 Goellner-Scheiding, Ursula; Humboldt Univ, Leibniz Inst Evolut &
   Biodiversitatsforsch, Invalidenstr 43, Berlin, D-10115, Germany,
   Germany.
SC Zoology
SN 0005-805X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Key;
   Documentation; Publications; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Agachila [Checklists / Species checklist / Systematics] [Africa /  /
   Biology; distribution]. 
   Agachila barbarae [Tanzania /  / New species]. 
   Agachila constanti [Congo-Kinshasa /  / New species] [Kenya /  / ]. 
   Agachila heinrichae [Congo-Kinshasa /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Heteroptera, Cimicomorpha,
   Tingoidea, Tingidae
OR Agachila - Drake & Gomez-Menor 1954 (Tingidae): [Key to species, P.
   245]. 
   Agachila abimva - (Schouteden 1953) (Tingidae): [Syn nov, Agachila
   biafranca Drake & Gomez-Menor 1954, p. 237]. 
   Agachila barbarae (Tingidae): [Sp nov, Tanzania, P. 237]. 
   Agachila constanti (Tingidae): [Sp nov, Congo-Kinshasa, P. 238]. 
   Agachila heinrichae (Tingidae): [Sp nov, Congo-Kinshasa, P. 240].

AN ZOOR14810069743
DT Article
TI Identity of Omphalocera hirta South, 1901 (Pyraloidea, Pyralidae), a
   little known pyralid from East Asia.
AU Sohn, Jae-Cheon
SO Tinea
VL 22
IS 1
PS 1-5
PD 15 May 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A very little known pyralid, Omphalocera hirta South, is redescribed
   with a new generic combination to Omphalomia. Lectotypes of Omphalocera
   hirta and Omphalomia accersita Swinhoe are designated here. Those two
   similar species are compared in the external appearance and the male
   genitalia.
C1 Sohn, Jae-Cheon; Department of Entomology, University of Maryland,
   College Park, MD 20742, USA, USA.
SC Zoology
SN 0493-3168
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Type material; Description; Combination;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Pyraloidea, Pyralidae
OR Omphalocera hirta - South in Leech 1901 (Pyralidae): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 4; Referred to, Omphalomia, p. 2]. 
   Omphalomia accersita - Swinhoe 1894 (Pyralidae): [Lectotype designated,
   P. 2, Attributable to Shaffer 1978]. 
   Omphalomia hirta - (South in Leech 1901) (Pyralidae): [Redescription, P.
   2; Comb nov, Transferred from Omphalocera, p. 2].

TI New Notodontidae species in Southeast Asia (2) (Notodontidae,
   Lepidoptera).
AU Kobayashi, Hideki
SO Tinea
VL 22
IS 1
PS 6-11
PD 15 May 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB New species of Somera Walker, 1855, Pseudogargetta Bethune-Baker, 1904
   and a new subspecies of Ortholomia Felder, 1861 from Indonesia are
   described: Somera viriviri sp. nov., Pseudogargetta orbiculata sp. nov.,
   Ortholomia osica sulawesiensis ssp. nov. A replacement name, Ambadra
   arta nom. nov., is proposed for Ambadra gracilis Kobayashi, 2011, a
   junior homonym of Ambadra gracilis Holloway, 2011.
C1 Kobayashi, Hideki; Higashiyama 2-23-A-1211, Meguro-ku, Tokyo, 153-0043,
   Japan, Japan.

   Ukamenia dimorpha; Olethreutini: Eudemis arnatniensis, Pseudohedya
   rubellana; Enarmonini: Enarmonia aritai; Eucosmini: Spilonota amamiana,
   Lepteucosma kamasazrae, L. hirokovamamotoae, Phaneta nagaii. The adults
   and genitalia are illustrated.

DT Article
TI New records of lichen-moths from the Nanling Mts., Guangdong, South
   China, with descriptions of new genera and species (Lepidoptera,
   Arctiidae: Lithosiinae).
AU Dubatolov, Vladimir V.
   Kishida, Yasunori
   Wang, Min
SO Tinea
VL 22
IS 1
PS 25-52
PD 15 May 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB 41 species are recorded from Guangdong; they were collected in Nanling
   Mts. including 12 new species and one subspecies: Katha nankushanica sp.
   nov., K. magnata nanlingica ssp. nov., Dolgoma nigrocribrata sp. nov.,
   Wittia vazakii sp. nov., Gampola sinica sp. nov., Miltochrista
   obscuripostica sp. nov., Cyclomilta fangchenglaiae sp. nov., Nudaria
   debilis sp. nov. and N. vernalis sp. nov., Microlithosia nanlingica sp.
   nov., as well as three new species of the new genus Danielithosia gen.
   nov. (type species Tigrioides aureolata Daniel, 1954: D. fuscipennis sp.
   nov., D. consimilis sp. nov., D. difficilis sp. nov. Tigrioides limayca
   Daniel, 1954, T. pallens Inoue, 1980 and T. immaculata (Butler, 1880)
   are transferred into Danielithosia. Several species are transferred into
   another genera: Eilema stigma Fang, 2000 and Oeonistis subuigra Leech,
   1899 into Asiapistosia gen. nov., Lithosia conformis Walker, 1854, L.
   chekiangica Daniel, 1954, L. magnata Matsumura, 1927 - into Katha Moore,
   1878, Lithosia nigripars Walker, 1856 and llama tecta Wileman, 1910 -
   into Ghoria Moore, 1878, Lithosia japonica Leech, [1889], L. hunanica
   Daniel, 1954 - into Manulea Wallengren, 1863, Systropha klapperichi
   Daniel, 1954 - into Wittia de Freina, 1980, Eilema umbripuncta (de
   Joannis, 1928) - into Microlithosia Daniel, 1954, Eugoa roseivena
   Hampson, 1894 - into Planovalvata gen. nov., Miltochrista dimidiata
   Fang, 1991, M. compar Fang, 1991, M..sinuata Fang, 1991 and M.
   longstriga Fang, 1991 - into Barsine Walker, 1854. Paraona Moore, 1878
   is restored in the generic status from a synonym of Ghoria Moore, 1878.
   Stictane rectilinea chinesica Draudt, 1931 is raised to the specific
   status.
C1 Dubatolov, Vladimir V.; Siberian Zoological Museum, Institute of Animal
   Systematics and Ecology, SB RAS, Frunze Street 11, Novosibirsk 91,
   630091, Russia, Russia.
SC Zoology
SN 0493-3168

   Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Status; Land zones; Palaearctic

DT Article
TI A new genus and two new species of Nolinae from Northern Thailand
   (Lepidoptera: Nolidae).
AU Pellinen, Markku J. (markku.j.pellinen@gmail.com) 
SO Tinea
VL 22
IS 1
PS 61-66
PD 15 May 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new Nolinae (Lepidoptera: Nolidae) species and one new genus are
   described: Membranola new genus, with one constituent species, M.
   Lampang new species and Nola basinigra new species. Both new species are
   known thus far only from the type locality, Lampang, Northern Thailand;
   their biology and immature stages are unknown. The hitherto unknown
   female of Leuconola herczigi Lazlo et al. 2010. is described. All new
   taxa are diagnosed and illustrated, including the genitalia. and their
   systematic position is discussed. When the new species are considered, a
   total of 17 genera and 129 Nolinae species are reported from Northern
   Thailand.
C1 Pellinen, Markku J.; 175 M 1, Muban Phichai, Lampang, 52000, Thailand,
   Thailand.
EM markku.j.pellinen@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0493-3168

   region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Membranola basinigra; Membranola lampang [Thailand /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Noctuoidea, Nolidae

   described, Female, p. 66].

TI Notes of the Japanese Peoriini (Phycitinae, Pyralidae), with
   descriptions of fourteen new species.
AU Sasaki, Akio
SO Tinea
VL 22
IS 1
PS 75-96
PD 15 May 2012
PY 2012
LA Japanese
U1 0
U2 0
AB In studying Japanese Peoriini, I recognized twenty one species,
   including three new genera (Toshitamia, Hosomeiga, Paraemmalocera) and
   fourteen new species. Japanese species of the Peoriini: Hypsotropa
   solipunctella Ragonot, Enosima leucotaeniella (Ragonot), Rhinaphe
   flavescentella (Hampson), R. minor sp. n., Toshitamia komatsui sp. n.,
   T. tsushimensis sp. n., T. magna sp. n., Hosomeiga fujihirai sp. n., H.
   rubella sp. n., Polyocha diversella Hampson, P. rusticana sp. n.,
   Emmalocera venosella (Wileman), Paraemmalocera gensanalis (South)
   comb.n., P. anerastica (Snellen) comb. n., P. flava sp. n., P. rufa sp.
   n., Peoria ohkurai sp. n., Maliarpha borealis sp. n., Arivaca gracilis
   sp. n., A. pulchra sp. n., A. kudoi sp. n. The following three species,
   recorded from Japan in the past, could not be examined in this study:
   Osakia lineolella Ragonot, 1901, Raphimetopus ablutellus (Zeller, 1839)
   and Critonia roseistrigella Hampson, 1896.

PT J

PM 22585303
DT Article
TI Pseudocollinia brintoni gen. nov., sp. nov. (Apostomatida: Colliniidae),
   a parasitoid ciliate infecting the euphausiid Nyctiphanes simplex.
AU Gomez-Gutierrez, J. (jagomezg@ipn.mx) 
   Strueder-Kypke, M.C.
   Lynn, D.H.
   Shaw, T.C.
   Aguilar-Mendez, M.J.
   Lopez-Cortes, A.
   Martinez-Gomez, S.
   Robinson, C.J.
SO Diseases of Aquatic Organisms
VL 99
IS 1
PS 57-78
PD May 15 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 12
AB A novel parasitoid ciliate, Pseudocollinia brintoni gen. nov., sp. nov.
   was discovered infecting the subtropical sac-spawning euphausiid
   Nyctiphanes simplex off both coasts of the Baja California peninsula,
   Mexico. We used microscopic, and genetic information to describe this
   species throughout most of its life cycle. Pseudocollinia is
   distinguished from other Colliniidae genera because it exclusively
   infects euphausiids, has a polymorphic life cycle, and has a small
   cone-shaped oral cavity whose left wall has a field of ciliated
   kinetosomes and whose opening is surrounded on the left and right by 2
   'oral' kineties (or ciliary rows) that terminate at its anterior border.
   Two related species that infect different euphausiid species from higher
   latitudes in the northeastern Pacific Ocean, Collinia beringensis
   Capriulo and Small, 1986, briefly redescribed herein, and Collinia
   oregonensis Gomez-Gutierrez, Peterson, and Morado, 2006, are transferred
   to the genus Pseudocollinia. P. brintoni has between 12 and 18 somatic
   kineties, and its oral cavity has only 2 oral kineties, while P.
   beringensis comb. nov. has more somatic kineties, including 3 oral
   kineties. P. oregonensis comb. nov. has an intermediate number of
   somatic kineties. P. beringensis comb. nov. also infects Thysanoessa
   raschi (a new host species). SSU rRNA and cox1 gene sequences
   demonstrated that Pseudocollinia ciliates are apostome ciliates and that
   P. brintoni is different from P. beringensis comb. nov. High densities
   of rod-shaped bacteria (1.7 [mu]m length, 0.2 to 0.5 [mu]m diameter)
   were associated with P. brintoni. After euphausiid rupture, high
   concentrations of P. brintoni and bacteria cluster to form 3 to 6 cm
   long filaments where tomites encyst and transform to the phoront stage;
   this is a novel place for encystation. P. brintoni may complete its life
   cycle when the euphausiids feed on these filaments.
C1 Gomez-Gutierrez, J.; Ctr Interdisciplinario Ciencias Marinas, Dept
   Plancton & Ecol Marina, Av IPN S-N,AP 592, La Paz, Baja Calif Sur,
   23096, Mexico, Mexico.
EM jagomezg@ipn.mx
RI Lopez-Cortes, Alejandro/AAF-7147-2020; Strueder-Kypke,
   Michaela/H-9880-2019
OI Lopez-Cortes, Alejandro/0000-0002-7567-3133; Strueder-Kypke,
   Michaela/0000-0002-0805-878X
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 0177-5103
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Combination; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Hosts;
   Marine zones; Pacific Ocean; North Pacific
DE Nyctiphanes simplex [Protozoan parasites / Pseudocollinia brintoni / New
   parasite species] [North Pacific / Mexico / New protozoan parasite
   species]. 
   Pseudocollinia beringensis [Crustacean hosts / Thysanoessa raschi / New
   record] [Bering Sea /  / ]. 
   Pseudocollinia brintoni [Crustacean hosts / Nyctiphanes simplex / New
   parasite species] [North Pacific / Mexico / New species from crustacean
   host]. 
   Thysanoessa raschi [Protozoan parasites / Pseudocollinia beringensis /
   New record] [Bering Sea /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates; Protozoans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Euphausiacea, Protozoa, Ciliophora, Kinetofragminophorea, Hypostomatia,
   Apostomatida
OR Nyctiphanes simplex (Euphausiacea): [Host]. 
   Thysanoessa raschi (Euphausiacea): [Host; New record]. 
   Collinia beringensis - Capriulo & Small 1986 (Apostomatida): [Referred
   to, New genus Pseudocollinia, p. 73]. 
   Collinia oregonensis - Gomez-Gutierrez et al. 2006 (Apostomatida):
   [Referred to, New genus Pseudocollinia, p. 73]. 
   Pseudocollinia (Apostomatida): [Gen nov, Of family Colliniidae, Type
   species Pseudocollinia brintoni, p. 76]. 
   Pseudocollinia beringensis - (Capriulo & Small 1986) (Apostomatida):
   [Redescription, P. 66; Comb nov, Transferred from Collinia, p. 73;
   Parasite; New record]. 
   Pseudocollinia brintoni (Apostomatida): [Sp nov, Mexico (marine),
   Parasite of Nyctiphanes simplex (Crustacea), p. 76; Parasite]. 
   Pseudocollinia oregonensis - (Gomez-Gutierrez et al. 2006)
   (Apostomatida): [Comb nov, Transferred from Collinia, p. 73]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14808056518
