AN ZOOR14805040881
DT Article
TI Swedish Plectida (Nematoda). Part 1. Domorganus suecicus sp. n. from
   Skagerrak.
AU Holovachov, Oleksandr (holovachov@gmail.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3263
PS 63-68
PD 9 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3263.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03263p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of Domorganus, D. suecicus sp. n., is described from
   bottom sediments collected in Skagerrak off the west coast of Sweden. It
   is characterised by its long body (1.3-1.6 mm), lateral field
   originating immediately posterior to amphid, excretory pore located at
   the level of basal pharyngeal bulb, absence of advulval sensilla,
   straight spicules and absence of gubernaculum. The new species has a
   unique set of characters (position of excretory pore and absence of the
   gubernaculum) separating it from all other known species of the genus.
   It shows some resemblance to the previously described species D. acutus
   and D. subtilis in body size and most measurements, but can be easily
   separated from both by the relatively longer tail, shorter spicules,
   position of the anterior end of the lateral field near amphid, position
   of the excretory pore anterior to pharyngo-intestinal junction, and
   absence of gubernaculum. A tabular compendium of species of the genus
   Domorganus is also given.
C1 Holovachov, Oleksandr; Department of Invertebrate Zoology, Swedish
   Museum of Natural History, Box 50007, SE-104 05 Stockholm, Sweden,
   Sweden.
EM holovachov@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Marine zones; Atlantic
   Ocean; North Atlantic
DE Domorganus suecicus [Baltic Sea / Sweden / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Nematoda
OR Domorganus (Nematoda): [Diagnostic characters of subordinate taxa, P.
   67]. 
   Domorganus suecicus (Nematoda): [Sp nov, Sweden (marine), P. 64]. 
DI 10.11646/zootaxa.3263.1.3

PT J
AN ZOOR14806042082
DT Article
TI DNA barcodes reveal that the widespread European tortricid moth
   Phalonidia manniana (Lepidoptera: Tortricidae) is a mixture of two
   species.
AU Mutanen, Marko (marko.mutanen@oulu.fi) 
   Aarvik, Leif
   Huemer, Peter
   Kaila, Lauri
   Karsholt, Ole
   Tuck, Kevin
SO Zootaxa
VL 3262
PS 1-21
PD 9 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3262.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03262p021.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB During efforts to generate DNA barcodes for all North European
   Lepidoptera, Phalonidia manniana (Fischer von Roslerstamm, 1839) was
   found to comprise two genetically distinct clusters. Morphological
   investigation further supports the existence of two distinct taxa, P.
   manniana and P. udana Guenee, 1845, sp. rev. Their biologies also
   differ, P. manniana feeding in stems of Mentha and Lycopus (Lamiaceae)
   and P. udana feeding in stems of Lysimachia thyrsiflora and L. vulgaris
   (Primulaceae). We provide re-descriptions of both taxa and DNA barcodes
   for North European Phalonidia and Gynnidomorpha. Phalonidia tolli
   Razowski, 1960, syn. nov., is considered a junior synonym of Pudana.
   Phalonidia udana is widely distributed in the North Palaearctic, whereas
   it seems to be rare or missing in large parts of Central Europe. The
   study demonstrates the usefulness of DNA barcoding in revealing cryptic
   species.
C1 Mutanen, Marko; Zoological Museum, Department of Biology, PO Box 3000,
   FI-90014 University of Oulu, Finland, Finland.
EM marko.mutanen@oulu.fi
OI Kaila, Lauri/0000-0003-0277-1872
SC Zoology; Biochemistry &Molecular Biology; Genetics &Heredity;
   Evolutionary Biology; Nutrition &Dietetics; Developmental Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Description; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Status;
   Techniques; Biochemistry; Nutrition; Diet; Life cycle and development;
   Genetics; Evolution; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia
DE Gynnidomorpha; Phalonidia [Nucleic acids / DNA barcodes / ] [Molecular
   genetics /  / ] [Phylogeny / Molecular phylogeny / ]. 
   Phalonidia manniana species complex [Identification techniques / DNA
   barcoding / host preference; taxonomic implications] [Food plants /  / ]
   [Life cycle / Life history / ] [Molecular genetics /  / ] [Speciation /
   Cryptic speciation / ] [Europe /  / distribution]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Tortricoidea, Tortricidae
OR Gynnidomorpha (Tortricidae). 
   Phalonidia (Tortricidae). 
   Phalonidia manniana - (Fischer von Roeslerstamm 1839) (Tortricidae):
   [Redescription, P. 9]. 
   Phalonidia manniana species complex (Tortricidae). 
   Phalonidia udana - (Guenee 1845) (Tortricidae): [Redescription, P. 4;
   Syn nov, Phalonidia tolli Razowski 1960, p. 4; Stat rev, P. 4]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14806042082
DA 2020-09-17

TI A new genus related to the genus Lambis Roeding, 1798 (Gastropoda:
   Strombidae) from the Indian Ocean.

AB The genus Lambis Roeding, 1798 is discussed. A new genus based on
   conchological differences is recognized for which the name
   Ophioglossolambis gen. nov. is introduced.

DT Article
TI Middle Eocene rodents from Peruvian Amazonia reveal the pattern and
   timing of caviomorph origins and biogeography.
AU Antoine, Pierre-Olivier (pierre-olivier.antoine@univ-montp2.fr) 
   Marivaux, Laurent
   Croft, Darin A.
   Billet, Guillaume
   Ganerod, Morgan
   Jaramillo, Carlos
   Martin, Thomas
   Orliac, Maeva J.
   Tejada, Julia
   Altamirano, Ali J.
   Duranthon, Francis
   Fanjat, Gregory
   Rousse, Sonia
   Salas Gismondi, Rodolfo
SO Proceedings of the Royal Society Biological Sciences Series B
VL 279
IS 1732
PS 1319-1326
PD Apr 7 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 36
AB The long-term isolation of South America during most of the Cenozoic
   produced a highly peculiar terrestrial vertebrate biota, with a wide
   array of mammal groups, among which caviomorph rodents and platyrrhine
   Primates are Mid-Cenozoic immigrants. In the absence of indisputable
   pre-Oligocene South American rodents or Primates, the mode, timing and
   biogeography of these extraordinary dispersals remained debated. Here,
   we describe South America's oldest known rodents, based on a new diverse
   caviomorph assemblage from the late Middle Eocene (approx. 41 Ma) of
   Peru, including five small rodents with three stem caviomorphs. Instead
   of being tied to the Eocene/Oligocene global cooling and drying episode
   (approx. 34 Ma), as previously considered, the arrival of caviomorphs
   and their initial radiation in South America probably occurred under
   much warmer and wetter conditions, around the Mid-Eocene Climatic
   Optimum. Our phylogenetic results reaffirm the African origin of South
   American rodents and support a trans-Atlantic dispersal of these mammals
   during Middle Eocene times. This discovery further extends the gap
   (approx. 15 Myr) between first appearances of rodents and Primates in
   South America.
C1 Antoine, Pierre-Olivier; Univ Montpellier 2, CNRS, Montpellier, F-34095,
   France, France.
EM pierre-olivier.antoine@univ-montp2.fr
RI ROUSSE, Sonia/L-9325-2017
OI Orliac, Maeva/0000-0002-8922-8356; BILLET, Guillaume/0000-0002-3200-1548
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology;
   Meteorology &Atmospheric Sciences; Paleontology
SN 0962-8452
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Evolution; Abiotic factors;
   Physical factors; Zoogeography; Land zones; Neotropical region; South
   America; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene
DE Cachiyacuy; Canaanimys [Eocene /  / New genus]. 
   Cachiyacuy contamanensis; Cachiyacuy kummeli; Canaanimys maquiensis
   [Peru /  / new species] [Eocene /  / ]. 
   Caviomorpha [Origin of taxon /  / ] [Phylogeny /  / ] [Climate and
   weather /  / ] [Dispersal /  / ] [Palaeogene /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Rodents; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Rodentia
OR Cachiyacuy (Rodentia): [Gen nov, Of parvorder Caviomorpha, Type species
   Cachiyacuy contamanensis, p. 1320, Eocene; Fossil]. 
   Cachiyacuy contamanensis (Rodentia): [Sp nov, Peru, Eocene, P. 1321;
   Fossil]. 
   Cachiyacuy kummeli (Rodentia): [Sp nov, Peru, Eocene, P. 1321; Fossil]. 
   Canaanimys (Rodentia): [Gen nov, Of parvorder Caviomorpha1321, Type
   species Canaanimys maquiensis, p. 1321, Eocene; Fossil]. 
   Canaanimys maquiensis (Rodentia): [Sp nov, Peru, Eocene, P. 1321;
   Fossil]. 
   Caviomorpha (Rodentia): [Fossil].

DT Article
TI New Taxa and Combinations in Onciderini Thomson, 1860 (Coleoptera:
   Cerambycidae: Lamiinae) from Central and South America, with notes on
   additional taxa.
AU Nearns, Eugenio H. (gnearns@unm.edu) 
   Tavakilian, Gerard-Luc
SO Insecta Mundi
VL 0231
PS 1-24
PD April 6 2012
PY 2012
UR http://centerforsystematicentomology.org/insectamundi/0231NearnsandTavak
   ilian.pdf
AW http://centerforsystematicentomology.org/insectamundi/0231NearnsandTavak
   ilian.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Touroultia, a new genus of Onciderini Thomson, 1860 (Coleoptera:
   Cerambycidae: Lamiinae) is described and illustrated. Five new species
   of Onciderini are also described and illustrated: Jamesia ramirezi from
   Costa Rica; Peritrox marcelae from French Guiana; Touroultia swifti from
   Ecuador; Touroultia lordi from French Guiana; Trestoncideres
   santossilvai from Brazil. Keys to the known species of Peritrox Bates,
   1865; Touroultia gen. nov.; and Trestoncideres Martins and Galileo, 1990
   are provided. The following new synonymies are proposed: Calliphenges
   Waterhouse, 1880 (Colobotheini) = Malthonea Thomson, 1864
   (Desmiphorini); Paraclytemnestra Breuning, 1974 (Onciderini) = Jamesia
   Jekel, 1861 (Onciderini); Orteguaza Lane, 1958 (Apomecynini) =
   Clavidesmus Dillon and Dillon, 1946 (Onciderini). The following new
   combinations are proposed: Clavidesmus funerarius (Lane, 1958)
   (Onciderini); Clavidesmus lichenigerus (Lane, 1958) (Onciderini);
   Ischiocentra insulata (Rodrigues and Mermudes, 2011); Malthonea
   cuprascens (Waterhouse, 1880) (Desmiphorini); Touroultia obscurella
   (Bates, 1865) (Onciderini). The following species is restored to
   original combination: Jamesia lineata Fisher, 1926 (Onciderini). The
   fol- lowing 13 new country records are reported: Ataxia hovorei
   Lingafelter and Nearns, 2007 (Pteropliini) (Haiti); Carterica soror
   Belon, 1896 (Colobotheini) (Ecuador); Colobothea lunulata Lucas, 1859
   (Colobotheini) (Colombia); Curius punctatus (Fisher, 1932) (Curiini)
   (Haiti); Cyclopeplus lacordairei Thomson, 1868 (Anisocerini) (Colombia);
   Iarucanga mimica (Bates, 1866) (Hemilophini) (Ecuador); Pirangoclytus
   latithorax (Martins and Galileo, 2008) (Clytini) (Costa Rica);
   Porangonycha princeps (Bates, 1872) (Hemilophini) (Colombia); Trestonia
   lateapicata Mar- tins and Galileo, 2010 (Onciderini) (Brazil); Tulcus
   dimidiatus (Bates, 1865) (Onciderini) (Colombia); Unaporanga cincta
   Martins and Galileo, 2007 (Hemilophini) (Colombia); Zeale dubia Galileo
   and Martins, 1997 (Hemilophini) (Colombia); Zonotylus interruptus
   (Olivier, 1790) (Trachyderini) (Colombia).

DT Article
TI Systematic revision of Gonaphodiellus taxa, with description of two new
   genera and fourteen new species (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae: Aphodiinae).
AU Dellacasa, Marco (dellacasa@museo.unipi.it) 
   Dellacasa, Giovanni
   Gordon, Robert D.
SO Insecta Mundi
VL 0230
PS 1-41
PD April 6 2012
PY 2012
UR http://centerforsystematicentomology.org/insectamundi/0230Dellacasaetal.
   pdf
AW http://centerforsystematicentomology.org/insectamundi/0230Dellacasaetal.
   pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The American species belonging to the genus Gonaphodiellus Schmidt
   (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae: Aphodiinae) are redescribed and figured. Two
   new genera are described: Gonaphodioides and Gonaphodiopsis. Fourteen
   new species are described: Gonaphodiellus arcanus, G. cerropuntanus, G.
   manantlanicus, G. martinpierai, G. omiltemicus, G. sacatepequezis,
   Gonaphodioides newtoni, G. ratcliffei, G. skelleyi, Gonaphodiopsis
   deloyai, G. hypogea, G. montesdeocai, G. pachecoi, G. teopiscaensis. The
   lectotype of Aphodius columbicus (Harold, 1880) is designated. The
   following new combinations are proposed: Gonaphodiellus nigrinus
   (Schmidt, 1916), Gonaphodioides acutecernans (Balthasar, 1960),
   Gonaphodioides chapini (Hinton, 1934), Gonaphodioides columbicus
   (Harold, 1880), Gonaphodioides sincerus (Petrovitz, 1973). Aphodius
   (Gonaphodiellus) xalapensis Galante, Stebnicka and Verdu, 2003 is placed
   as a junior synonym of Gonaphodiellus bimaculosus (Schmidt, 1909), new
   synonymy. Aphodius ataenioides Hinton, 1938 and Aphodius (Blackburneus)
   castanescens Petrovitz, 1973 are placed as junior synonyms of
   Gonaphodioides chapini (Hinton, 1934), new synonymies.
C1 Dellacasa, Marco; Museo di Storia Naturale e del Territorio, Universita
   di Pisa, Via Roma, 79, I-56011 Calci (Pisa), Italy, Italy.
EM dellacasa@museo.unipi.it

   America; Central America

DT Article
TI The Genus Chimarra Stephens (Trichoptera: Philopotamidae) in Vietnam.
AU Blahnik, Roger J. (blahn003@umn.edu) 
   Arefina-Armitage, Tatiana I.
   Armitage, Brian J.
SO Insecta Mundi
VL 0229
PS 1-25
PD April 6 2012
PY 2012
UR http://centerforsystematicentomology.org/insectamundi/0229Blahniketal.pd
   f
AW http://centerforsystematicentomology.org/insectamundi/0229Blahniketal.pd
   f
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Currently, the genus Chimarra Stephens (Trichoptera: Philopotamidae) is
   represented in the Oriental Region by 259 species. Of these, 61 species
   have been described or recorded from Vietnam. In this paper, 9 new
   species from Vietnam are described and illustrated (Chimarra aculeata,
   C. carinata, C. corneola, C. insolita, C. mina, C. prominens, C.
   rostrata, C. undulata, and C. ungula). In addition, 3 new country
   records are noted (Chimarra areli Malicky and Mey, Chimarra pipake
   Malicky and Chantaramongkol, and Chimarra suthepensis Chantaramongkol
   and Malicky), and 1 new species group (minuta Group) is proposed and
   populated. An additional species group (georgensis "Group"), with 1 new
   species from Vietnam, but otherwise only known from Africa, is
   discussed, but not formally defined. A table listing all known
   Vietnamese species of Chimarra is included, along with discussion of
   variability in the anal veins of the forewing found within this genus,
   and its relevance for defining subgenera and species groups.
C1 Blahnik, Roger J.; Department of Entomology, 1980 Folwell Ave., 219
   Hodson Hall, University of Minnesota, St. Paul, MN 55108, USA, USA.
EM blahn003@umn.edu
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology
SN 0749-6737; 1942-1354

   Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia

   systematics] [Vietnam /  / distribution]. 
   Chimarra aculeata; Chimarra carinata; Chimarra corneola; Chimarra
   insolita; Chimarra mina; Chimarra prominens; Chimarra rostrata; Chimarra
   undulata; Chimarra ungula [Vietnam /  / New species]. 
   Chimarra areli; Chimarra pipake; Chimarra suthepensis [Vietnam /  / New
   record]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Trichoptera
OR Chimarra - Stephens 1829 (Trichoptera): [New record]. 
   Chimarra aculeata (Trichoptera): [Sp nov, Vietnam, P. 4]. 
   Chimarra areli (Trichoptera): [New record]. 
   Chimarra carinata (Trichoptera): [Sp nov, Vietnam, P. 21]. 
   Chimarra corneola (Trichoptera): [Sp nov, Vietnam, P. 19]. 
   Chimarra insolita (Trichoptera): [Sp nov, Vietnam, P. 6].

DT Article
TI A new species of Stenorrhachus McLachlan from Chile (Neuroptera:
   Nemopteridae) with biological notes.
AU Miller, Robert B. (glenurus@gmail.com) 
   Stange, Lionel A.

AB A new species of Stenorrhachus (McLachlan), S. chilensis (Neuroptera:
   Nemopteridae), is described from Chile with biological observations of
   Stenorrhachus walkeri (McLachlan). A key to the two species is provided
   as well as diagnoses of the adults and of the larva of Stenorrhachus
   walkeri.

TI Two new species of the genus Pahamunaya Schmid (Trichoptera:
   Polycentropodidae) from Vietnam.
AU Arefina-Armitage, Tatiana I. (tobikera@gmail.com) 
   Armitage, Brian J.
SO Insecta Mundi
VL 0225
PS 1-6
PD April 6 2012
PY 2012
UR http://centerforsystematicentomology.org/insectamundi/0225ArefinaandArmi
   tage.pdf
AW http://centerforsystematicentomology.org/insectamundi/0225ArefinaandArmi
   tage.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of the genus Pahamunaya Schmid (Trichoptera:
   Polycentropodidae), P. talon sp. n. and P. spinifera sp. n., from
   Vietnam are described and illustrated. Examination of the holotype male
   of P. khoii Olah and Johanson, in combination with an additional
   specimen of the same species, revealed new characters. New illustrations
   for this species are provided.

   Columbus, OH 43221-0039, USA, USA.

DT Article
TI New species, records, and a synonymy of African Sisyridae (Neuroptera).
AU Flint, Oliver S., Jr (flinto@si.edu) 
SO Insecta Mundi
VL 0223
PS 1-6
PD April 6 2012
PY 2012
UR http://centerforsystematicentomology.org/insectamundi/0223Flint.pdf
AW http://centerforsystematicentomology.org/insectamundi/0223Flint.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two species of the genus Sisyra Burmeister (Neuroptera: Sisyridae), S.
   cameroonensis, n. sp., and S. gruwelli, n. sp., are described from the
   African Republic of Cameroon. Sisyra pallida Meinander is synonymized
   with Sisyra delicata Smithers, new synonymy, after comparison of the
   types of the former with topotypic paratypes of the latter. Type
   material of Sisyra nilotica Tjeder appears to be lost. Examples of
   Sisyra are recorded from Nigeria, Ethiopia and Uganda. A second species
   of the endemic African genus, Sisyborina, Monserrat, S. scitula, n. sp.,
   is described from Cameroon, Guinea, and Zambia.
C1 Flint, Oliver S., Jr; Department of Entomology, National Museum of
   Natural History, Smithsonian Institution, Washington, DC, 20013-7012,
   USA, USA.
EM flinto@si.edu
SC Zoology
SN 0749-6737; 1942-1354
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Land zones;
   Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Sisyborina scitula [Cameroon /  / New species] [Guinea /  / ] [Zambia / 
   / ]. 
   Sisyra cameroonensis; Sisyra gruwelli [Cameroon /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Neuroptera
OR Sisyborina scitula (Neuroptera): [Sp nov, Cameroon, P. 5]. 
   Sisyra cameroonensis (Neuroptera): [Sp nov, Cameroon, P. 2]. 
   Sisyra delicata - Smithers 1957 (Neuroptera): [Syn nov, Sisyra pallida
   Meinander 1978, p. 4]. 
   Sisyra gruwelli (Neuroptera): [Sp nov, Cameroon, P. 2]. 
   Sisyra nilotica - Tjeder 1957 (Neuroptera): [Species inquirenda, P. 4]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14805040830

DT Article
TI Taxonomic revision of the genus Glaucocharis Meyrick (Lepidoptera,
   Crambidae, Crambinae) from China, with descriptions of nine new species.
AU Li, Weichun (lihouhun@nankai.edu.cn) 
   Li, Houhun
SO Zootaxa
VL 3261
PS 1-32
PD 6 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3261.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03261p032.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Glaucocharis Meyrick is revised from China, with descriptions of nine
   new species: G. brevis sp. n., G. flavifasciaria sp. n., G. paulispinata
   sp. n., G. grandispinata sp. n., G. siciformis sp. n., G. tridentata sp.
   n., G. biconvexa sp. n., G. scrotiformis sp. n. and G. setosa sp. n.;
   Glaucocharis incisella (Bleszynski, 1970) and G. pilcheri Gaskin, 1988
   are newly recorded for China; the females of seven species are described
   for the first time: G. omeishani (Bleszynski, 1965), G. incisella
   (Bleszynski, 1970), G. parmulella Wang&Sung, 1988, G. pilcheri Gaskin,
   1988, G. longqiensis Song, 1993, G. huanggangensis Song&Chen, 2001 and
   G. hastatella Song&Chen, 2001. Images of the adults and illustrations of
   the genitalia for the new species are provided. The distribution data of
   the Chinese Glaucocharis are presented, along with a map showing the
   localities of these species.
C1 Li, Weichun; College of Life Sciences, Nankai University, Tianjin,
   300071, China, China.
EM lihouhun@nankai.edu.cn

PT J
AN ZOOR14805040883
DT Article
TI Revision of Palaearctic and Oriental Necrophila Kirby & Spence, part 2:
   subgenus Chrysosilpha Portevin (Coleoptera: Silphidae).
AU Ruzicka, Jan (ruzickajan@fzp.czu.cz) 
   Schneider, Jan
   Qubaiova, Jarin
   Nishikawa, Masaaki
SO Zootaxa
VL 3261
PS 33-58
PD 6 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3261.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/f/zt03261p058.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A taxonomic revision of the subgenus Chrysosilpha Portevin, 1921 (of the
   genus Necrophila Kirby&Spence, 1828) is presented. Three valid species
   are recognized: (1) N. (C.) formosa (Laporte, 1832), comb. nov. (ex
   Silpha Linnaeus, 1758), widely distributed from Laos and Vietnam through
   the Malay Peninsula, to Sumatra and Bali, with Silpha chloroptera
   Laporte, 1840 and Chrysosilpha chloroptera var. magnifica Portevin, 1921
   as newly established junior subjective synonyms; (2) N. (C.) renatae
   (Portevin, 1920), comb. nov. (ex Silpha), endemic to Sulawesi; and (3)
   N. (C.) viridis (Motschulsky, 1861), comb. nov. (ex Oiceoptoma Leach,
   1815), endemic to the Philippines. Lectotypes are designated for Silpha
   formosa Laporte, 1832; Silpha chloroptera Laporte, 1840 and Chrysosilpha
   chloroptera var. magnifica Portevin, 1921. Georeferenced records for all
   three species are mapped. Parsimony analysis supports the monophyly of
   Chrysosilpha, with N. (C.) formosa as the sister to a clade of N. (C.)
   renatae and N. (C.) viridis. Geometrical morphometrics (thin-plate
   spline) discriminated the three species of Chrysosilpha; the first two
   relative warp axes indicated 70.31% shape variation in males and 77.18%
   in females, which was further confirmed by MANOVA to be highly
   significant. Canonical variate analysis indicated no overlap between the
   three taxa and enabled a 100% correct classification of each specimen to
   its group mean.
C1 Ruzicka, Jan; Department of Ecology, Faculty of Environmental Sciences,
   Czech University of Life Sciences Prague, Kamycka 129, CZ-165 21 Praha
   6, Czech Republic, Czech Republic.
EM ruzickajan@fzp.czu.cz
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology; Environmental
   Sciences &Ecology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Type material; Combination; Synonymy;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Biometrics; Evolution; Ecology;
   Zoogeography; Land zones
DE Necrophila (Chrysosilpha) [Biometrics / Geometric morphometrics /
   systematics] [Phylogeny /  / ] [Ecology /  / ] [Zoogeography /  / ]
   [Oriental region /  / distribution]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Staphylinoidea,
   Silphidae
OR Chrysosilpha chloroptera var. magnifica - Portevin 1921 (Silphidae):
   [Lectotype designated, P. 38]. 
   Necrophila (Chrysosilpha) - Portevin 1921 (Silphidae): [Key to species,
   P. 38]. 
   Necrophila (Chrysosilpha) formosa - (Laporte 1832) (Silphidae): [Comb
   nov, Transferred from Silpha (Chrysosilpha), p. 38; Syn nov,
   Chrysosilpha chloroptera var. magnifica Portevin 1921, p. 38; Syn nov,
   Silpha chloroptera Laporte 1840, p. 38]. 
   Necrophila (Chrysosilpha) renatae - (Portevin 1920) (Silphidae): [Comb
   nov, Transferred from Silpha (Chrysosilpha), p. 40]. 
   Necrophila (Chrysosilpha) viridis - (Motschulsky 1861) (Silphidae):
   [Comb nov, Transferred from Oiceoptoma (Thanatophilus), p. 43]. 
   Oiceoptoma (Thanatophilus) viridis - Motschulsky 1861 (Silphidae):
   [Referred to, Necrophila (Chrysosilpha), p. 43]. 
   Silpha (Chrysosilpha) formosa - Laporte 1832 (Silphidae): [Referred to,
   Necrophila (Chrysosilpha), p. 38]. 
   Silpha (Chrysosilpha) renatae - (Portevin 1920) (Silphidae): [Referred
   to, Necrophila (Chrysosilpha), p. 40]. 
   Silpha chloroptera - Laporte 1840 (Silphidae): [Lectotype designated, P.
   38]. 
   Silpha formosa - Laporte 1832 (Silphidae): [Lectotype designated, P.
   38].

DT Article
TI Squamatinia algharbica gen. n. sp. n., a remarkable new Coletiniinae
   silverfish (Zygentoma: Nicoletiidae) from caves in southern Portugal.
AU Reboleira, Ana Sofia P.S. (sreboleira@ua.pt) 
   Goncalves, Fernando
   Oromi, Pedro
   Mendes, Luis F.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3260
PS 33-46
PD 6 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3260.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03260p046.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new genus of Coletiniinae silverfish (Nicoletiidae) similar to
   Coletinia Wygodzinsky and Lepidospora Escherich is described to
   accommodate the new species Squamatinia algharbica gen. n. sp. n. Many
   individuals were collected over all seasons of the year in four caves of
   the Algarve karst massif in the south of Portugal. An identification key
   for the known genera of Coletiniinae is provided, as well as some
   biogeographical and ecological comments.
C1 Reboleira, Ana Sofia P.S.; Departamento de Biologia CESAM - Centro de
   Estudos do Ambiente e do mar, Universidade de Aveiro, Campus
   Universitario de Santiago, 3810-193 Aveiro, Portugal, Portugal.
EM sreboleira@ua.pt

SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe

   Squamatinia - Mendes & Reboleira 2012 (Thysanura): [Gen nov, Of
   subfamily Coletiniinae, Type species Squamatinia algharbica, p. 35]. 
   Squamatinia algharbica - Mendes & Reboleira 2012 (Thysanura): [Sp nov,

DT Article
TI Zorotypus novobritannicus n. sp., the first species of the order
   Zoraptera (Zorotypidae) from the Australasian Ecozone.
AU Terry, Matthew D. (mterry1@utpa.edu) 
   Whiting, Michael F.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3260
PS 53-61
PD 6 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3260.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03260p061.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB Zorotypus novobritannicus n. sp. (Polyneoptera: Zoraptera: Zorotypidae)
   is described from the Australasian ecozone from males and females of
   both apterous and dealated morphs. The description includes detailed
   accounts of head and thorax of the eyeless apterous morphs, head of the
   dealated winged morph with both eyes and ocelli, and the male and female
   abdomen and terminalia. Zorotypus novobritannicus n. sp. has unique,
   palmate setae on the lateral and ventral sides of the cerci of both
   sexes and dealated winged morphs are found at much higher densities than
   have been reported for any other species of Zoraptera.
C1 Terry, Matthew D.; Department of Biology, University of Texas, Pan
   American, 1201 W University Dr, Edinburg, TX 78539, USA, USA.
EM mterry1@utpa.edu
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Australasian region;
   Australasia
DE Zoraptera; Zorotypus [Australasia /  / New record]. 
   Zorotypus novobritannicus [Papua New Guinea /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Zoraptera
OR Zoraptera (Insecta): [New record]. 
   Zorotypus (Zoraptera): [New record]. 
   Zorotypus novobritannicus (Zoraptera): [Sp nov, Papua New Guinea, P.
   54].

DT Article
TI Two newly recorded genera and three new species of the tribe Cedusini
   (Hemiptera: Fulgoromorpha: Derbidae) from Korea.
AU Rahman, Mohammad Atikur
   Kwon, Yong Jung (yjkwon@knu.ac.kr) 
   Suh, Sang Jae
SO Zootaxa
VL 3261
PS 59-68
PD 6 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3261.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03261p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three new derbid species, Produsa koreana sp. nov., Hauptenia
   palgongsanensis sp. nov. and Hauptenia tripartita sp. nov. of the tribe
   Cedusini (Hemiptera: Fulgoromorpha: Derbidae) are described and
   illustrated from Korea. They represent the first record of the genera
   Produsa Szwedo, 2006 and Hauptenia Szwedo, 2006 and the tribe Cedusini
   in the Korean fauna. Identification keys to the known species of Produsa
   and Hauptenia are provided.
C1 Kwon, Yong Jung; School of Applied Biosciences, Kyungpook National
   University, Daegu 702-701, South Korea, South Korea.
EM yjkwon@knu.ac.kr

   Korea /  / New species].

TI A new genus of leaf litter inhabiting Neotropical Monoplatina
   (Coleoptera: Chrysomelidae: Galerucinae: Alticini).
AU Linzmeier, Adelita M. (alinzmeier@yahoo.com.br) 
   Konstantinov, Alexander S.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3260
PS 19-32
PD 6 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3260.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03260p032.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus (Andersonaltica) containing five new species (A.
   denticulata, A. elongata, A. pecki - the type species of the genus, A.
   tuberosa, and A. valens) from Central America is described and
   illustrated. It is compared to Aedmon Clark, Apleuraltica Bechyne,
   Distigmoptera Blake, Hypolampsis Clark, and Pseudolampsis Horn and a key
   to identification of these genera is provided.

DT Article
TI Arthrodendron borberensis sp nov., a large protist (Foraminifera) from
   the Pagliaro Formation (Paleocene), Northern Apennines, Italy.
AU Uchman, Alfred (alfred.uchman@uj.edu.pl) 
   Kaminski, Michael A.
   Rattazzi, Bruno
SO Geological Quarterly
VL 56
IS 1
PS 215-224
PD April 5 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Arthrodendron borberensis sp. nov. is described from the Pagliaro
   Formation (Paleocene) of the Northern Apennines. Specimens of the new
   species are preserved on the sole of a turbiditic sandstone bed.
   Arthrodendron borberensis sp. nov. is characterized by its long chambers
   (some exceeding 10 mm in length), its generally straight course, and
   rare branching at an acute angle. This large foraminifer lived
   infaunally within the sediment and possibly as epifauna after exhumation
   by erosion, prior to the deposition of the host turbiditic sandstone
   bed. Assemblages of smaller agglutinated foraminifera (a flysch-type
   fauna) and trace fossils (Nereites ichnofacies) point to a deep-sea
   environment for the discussed protist.
C1 Uchman, Alfred; Jagiellonian Univ, Inst Geol Sci, Krakow, PL-30063,
   Poland, Poland.
EM alfred.uchman@uj.edu.pl
RI Kaminski, Michael/K-3334-2012
OI Uchman, Alfred/0000-0002-0591-777X
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1641-7291
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary;
   Palaeogene
DE Arthrodendron borberensis [Italy /  / new species] [Palaeocene /  / ]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Sarcomastigophora, Sarcodina, Rhizopoda, Granuloreticulosea,
   Foraminiferida
OR Arthrodendron borberensis (Foraminiferida): [Sp nov, Italy, Palaeocene,
   P. 217; Fossil].

DT Article
TI Insect galls found on Mikurajima and Aogashima, the Izu Islands, Tokyo,
   Japan.
AU Tokuda, Makoto
   Matsuo, Kazunori
   Yukawa, Junichi
SO Japanese Journal of Entomology New Series
VL 15
IS 2
PS 75-84
PD Apr 5 2012
PY 2012
LA Japanese
U1 0
U2 3
AB Cecidomyiid galls were surveyed in 2010 and 2011 for the first time on
   Mikurajima and Aogashima, the Izu Islands, Tokyo, Japan. We found 13 and
   three sorts of the galls on Mikurajima and Aogashima, respectively.
   Among them, the jar-shaped axillary bud gall induced by Rhopalomyia sp.
   was newly discovered on Chrysanthemum pacificum (Asteraceae). The stem
   gall induced by Bruggmanniella sp. on Actinodaphne acuminata (Lauraceae)
   was newly recorded from Tokyo. The following five sorts were new to the
   Izu Islands: the blister-shaped leaf gall induced by an unidentified
   cecidomyiid on Machilus thunbergii (Lauraceae), the axillary bud gall
   induced by Asteralobia soyogo on Ilex integra (Aquifoliaceae), the ovate
   leaf gall induced by Oxycephalomyia styraci on Styrax japonica
   (Styracaceae), the bud gall induced by Asphondylia baca on Weigela
   coraeensis var. fragrans (Caprifoliaceae), and the small ellipsoidal
   leaf gall induced by Rhopalomyia chrysanthemum on C. pacificum. In
   addition, the petiole gall induced by Paratephritis fukaii (Diptera:
   Tephritidae) on Farfugium hiberniflorum (Asteraceae) was newly recorded
   from the Izu Islands, and the leaf gall induced by Trioza cinnamomi
   (Hemiptera: Psylloidea) on Cinnamomum tenuifolium (Lauraceae) and the
   leaf gall induced by Liothrips kuwanai (Thysanoptera: Phlaeothripidae)
   on Piper kadsura (Piperaceae) were new to Mikurajima and Aogashima.
C1 Tokuda, Makoto; Saga Univ, Fac Agr, 1 Honjo, Saga, 8408502, Japan,
   Japan.
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 1343-8794
BD Parasites diseases and disorders; Hosts; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia

   Honshu, Izu Islands, Mikurajima &amp; Aogashima / ]. 
   Liothrips kuwanai [Plant hosts / Piper kadsura / New record; plant gall]
   [Japan / Honshu, Izu Islands / ]. 
   Paratephritis fukaii [Plant hosts / Farfugium hiberniflorum / New
   record; plant gall] [Japan / Honshu, Izu Islands / ]. 
   Trioza cinnamomi [Plant hosts / Cinnamomum tenuifolium / New record;
   plant gall] [Japan / Honshu, Izu Islands / ].

DT Article
TI A gigantic feathered dinosaur from the Lower Cretaceous of China.
AU Xu, Xing (xingxu@vip.sina.com) 
   Wang, Kebai
   Zhang, Ke
   Ma, Qingyu
   Xing, Lida
   Sullivan, Corwin
   Hu, Dongyu
   Cheng, Shuqing
   Wang, Shuo
SO Nature (London)
VL 484
IS 7392
PS 92-95
PD 5 April 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 3
U2 114
AB Numerous feathered dinosaur specimens have recently been recovered from
   the Middle-Upper Jurassic and Lower Cretaceous deposits of northeastern
   China, but most of them represent small animals1. Here we report the
   discovery of a gigantic new basal tyrannosauroid, Yutyrannus huali gen.
   et sp. nov., based on three nearly complete skeletons representing two
   distinct ontogenetic stages from the Lower Cretaceous Yixian Formation
   of Liaoning Province, China. Y.huali shares some features, particularly
   of the cranium, with derived tyrannosauroids 2, 3, but is similar to
   other basal tyrannosauroids4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12 in possessing a
   three-fingered manus and a typical theropod pes. Morphometric analysis
   suggests that Y.?huali differed from tyrannosaurids in its growth
   strategy13, 14. Most significantly, Y.huali bears long filamentous
   feathers, thus providing direct evidence for the presence of extensively
   feathered gigantic dinosaurs and offering new insights into early
   feather evolution.
C1 Xu, Xing; Institute of Vertebrate Paleontology and Paleoanthropology,
   Chinese Academy of Sciences, 142 Xizhimenwai Street, Beijing 100044,
   China, China.
EM xingxu@vip.sina.com
RI Wang, Shuo/AAX-8516-2020
OI Wang, Shuo/0000-0002-4076-0202; Xing, Lida/0000-0003-3923-9206;
   Sullivan, Corwin/0000-0002-5488-6797
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology
SN 0028-0836
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Integument; Integumentary
   derivatives; Plumage; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia;
   China; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Yutyrannus [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Yutyrannus huali [Feathers /  / Recorded; new species] [Liaoning /  / ]
   [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates

   Theropoda

   species Yutyrannus huali, p. 92, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Yutyrannus huali (Theropoda): [Sp nov, Liaoning, Cretaceous, P. 92;
   Fossil].

DT Article
TI Integrative taxonomy of Asiopodabrus fragiliformis (Kang and Kim, 2000)
   (Coleoptera: Cantharidae) and its related species.
AU Kang, Tae Hwa
   Han, Tae Man
   Okushima, Yuichi
   Park, Hae Chul (culent@chol.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3259
PS 1-33
PD 5 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3259.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03259p033.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Both the color patterns of the body and the structures of the male
   genitalia are important characters used in species identification of
   traditional taxonomy. However, these characters are often limiting when
   identifying females of some species. In this study, we attempted to
   evaluate the species reality of Asiopodabrus fragiliformis which often
   has difficulty in being identified due to individual variation in color
   pattern and lack of female information. Using DNA barcoding, A.
   fragiliformis was represented as having three clades strongly supported
   by a high bootstrap value (>99%) and with over 3% branch lengths having
   a 2.9[long dash]3.4% barcoding gap. Morphological reexamination based on
   the result of DNA barcoding, demonstrated three clades: A.
   fragiliformis, A. kurvatovi, and A. koryeoensis n. sp., respectively,
   that were clarified based on subtle difference in both male and female
   morphological characters. This study explicitly showed that DNA
   barcoding may clearly and rapidly decide the species delineation for
   morpho-species in certain cases when the identification of female
   specimens is not clear using traditional methods.
C1 Park, Hae Chul; Department of Agricultural Biology, National Academy of
   Agricultural Science, 61, Seodun-dong, Gweonseon-gu, Suwon-si, 441-100,
   South Korea, South Korea.
EM culent@chol.com
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; General morphology;
   Genetics; Evolution; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Asiopodabrus [General morphology /  / taxonomic implications] [Molecular
   genetics / DNA barcoding / ] [Phylogeny / Cladistics / ] [Asia /  / ]. 
   Asiopodabrus koryeoensis [South Korea /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates

   Cantharidae

   Asiopodabrus fragiliformis - Kang & Kim 2000 (Cantharidae): [Diagnostic

   Asiopodabrus koryeoensis (Cantharidae): [Sp nov, South Korea, P. 16]. 
   Asiopodabrus kurbatovi - Kazantsev 1998 (Cantharidae): [Diagnostic
   characters, P. 17].

TI Botrylloides pizoni, a new species of Botryllinae (Ascidiacea) from the
   Mediterranean Sea.
AU Brunetti, R. (ric.brunetti@gmail.com) 
   Mastrototaro, F.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3258
PS 28-36
PD 5 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3258.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/f/zt03258p036.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB A new ascidian species belonging to the Botryllinae was discovered in
   the Gulf of Taranto (South Italy). This new species was collected in
   different seasons over a period of several years, which allowed
   information about its biology to be obtained. The new species presents
   large zooids arranged in ladder systems. The zooids have several rows of
   stigmata, the second one complete, ovary posterior to testis, one larva
   per side developing in an incubatory pouch, and a peculiar arrangement
   of the gut loop. The new species is named Botrylloides pizoni after the
   great French zoologist Antoine Pizon (1860[long dash]1942).
C1 Brunetti, R.; Natural History Museum of Venice, S. Croce 1730, I-30135
   Venezia, Italy, Italy.
EM ric.brunetti@gmail.com

   Atlantic

TI Chaca serica, a new species of frogmouth catfish (Teleostei:
   Siluriformes) from southern Borneo.
AU Ng, Heok Hee (heokhee@nus.edu.sg) 
   Kottelat, Maurice
SO Zootaxa
VL 3258
PS 37-45
PD 5 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3258.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03258p045.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Chaca serica, a new species of frogmouth catfish from the Kahayan,
   Kapuas and Mentaya river drainages in southern Borneo, is described
   here. It can be distinguished from congeners in having the following
   combination of characters: the oral margin of the lower lip lacking (vs.
   having) a series of rugose ridges, presence of nasal barbels, presence
   of papillae around the eyes, a temporal fossa extending to the
   supraoccipital, 7[long dash]8 serrae on the anterior edge of the
   pectoral spine, four pectoral-fin rays, absence of a row of fimbriate
   skin flaps on the body dorsal to (and sometimes also ventral to) the
   lateral line, dorsal procurrent caudal-ray base 32.8[long dash]37.3% SL,
   and ventral procurrent caudal-ray base 16.0[long dash]19.2% SL.
C1 Ng, Heok Hee; Tropical Marine Science Institute, National University of
   Singapore, 18 Kent Ridge Road, 119227, Singapore, Singapore.

DT Article
TI One new and two known species of Dorylaimoidea (Nematoda) from West
   Bengal, India.
AU Sen, Debabrata (Debabrata.zsi@gmail.com) 
   Chatterjee, Amalendu
   Manna, Buddhadeb
SO Zootaxa
VL 3258
PS 46-57
PD 5 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3258.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03258p057.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Small populations of Laimydorus istvani sp. n., Laimydorus baldus
   Baqri&Jana, 1982 and Dorylaimus sp. were collected from the soil around
   the roots of guava at south 24-Parganas district, West Bengal, India.
   Laimydorus istvani sp. n. is characterized by its odontostyle being
   distinctly thicker than the cuticle at the same level, cardia shape:
   rounded-conoid, wide at pharyngo-intestinal junction, enveloped by
   intestinal tissue which forms a conical projection extending into the
   lumen of intestine; delicate ring-like structure between the pharyngeal
   base and the proper cardia. Laimydorus istvani sp. n. comes close to L.
   multialaeus (Khera, 1970) Baqri, 1985, L. siddiqii Baqri&Jana, 1982 and
   L. baldus Baqri&Jana, 1982, but can be distinguished from these species
   on the basis of different morphometric measurements. The new species
   differs from L.multialaeus in having higher a value, lower b value and
   longer odontostyle in females, and. longer body, lateral guiding pieces
   and tail in males. From L. siddiqii the new species differs in having a
   shorter tail in relation to body length, shorter cardia with different
   shape, shorter prerectum and longer rectum in female, different number
   of ventromedian supplements and shorter spicules in males. From L.
   baldus, it differs in having a longer body, greater a-value, longer
   odontostyle and odontophore and longer tail in females. Laimydorus
   istvani sp. n. differs from the males of L. baldus by its longer body,
   greater c value and in the number of ventromedian supplements. The
   population of L. baldus from West Bengal agrees well with the original
   description except for some variations in body, odontophore, prerectum
   and tail length. New data on male characters have been provided in the
   present study. The specimens of Dorylaimus sp. come close to D. geraerti
   Baqri&Jana, 1986 except in some morphometric measurements including: b
   (4.2.5.1 vs. 4.3.4.7), odontophore length (33.54 [mu]m vs. 40.43 [mu]m,
   prerectum length in females (120.160 [mu]m vs. 196.241 [mu]m and tail
   length in females (247.5.294 [mu]m vs. 249.406 [mu]m). In males, the
   supplements (36 in number) occur in a contiguous series (as is usually
   seen in the genus Dorylaimus Dujardin, 1845), whereas in the type
   specimens of D. geraerti 35.38 supplements are largely contiguous except
   for a set of 4.5 spaced supplements in the middle of the series, showing
   a resemblance with the genus Ischiodorylaimus Andrassy, 1969.
C1 Sen, Debabrata; Zoological Survey of India, M-Block, New Alipore,
   Kolkata-700 053, West Bengal, India, India.
EM Debabrata.zsi@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia; India; Marine zones; Indian Ocean; North Indian Ocean
DE Dorylaimus; Laimydorus baldus [West Bengal /  / Distribution;
   systematics] [Persian Gulf / Saudi Arabia, Jana / ]. 
   Laimydorus istvani [West Bengal /  / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Nematoda
OR Dorylaimus (Nematoda). 
   Laimydorus baldus - Baqri & Jana 1982 (Nematoda). 
   Laimydorus istvani (Nematoda): [Sp nov, West Bengal, P. 47].

PT J
AN ZOOR14805040697
DT Article
TI Nearctomeris, a new genus of Pill Millipedes from North America, with a
   comparison of genetic distances of American Pill Millipede Genera
   (Glomerida, Glomeridae).
AU Wesener, Thomas (thomas.wesener@rub.de) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3258
PS 58-68
PD 5 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3258.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03258p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB A new genus and species of the pill millipede order Glomerida,
   Nearctomeris inexpectata n. sp., n. gen., is described from the Eastern
   United States. The description of Nearctomeris brings the total number
   of American Glomerida genera to three. In two of three known
   localitites, Nearctomeris co-occurs with species of the genus Onomeris
   Cook, 1896. Onomeris and Nearctomeris have almost an identical size
   (4[long dash]5.5 mm) and dark colour, but can be readily distingusihed
   by numerous non-sexual and sexual characters. Sexual characters of the
   male telopod also place Nearctomeris into the family Glomeridae, while
   the third American pill millipede genus Glomeroides Chamberlin, 1922
   belongs to the Protoglomeridae. A key to all American genera of
   Glomerida is presented. For the first time in the order Glomerida, the
   partial cytochrome c oxidase I mitochondrial gene was analyzed for the
   three American genera of the Glomerida, Glomeroides, Onomeris, and
   Nearctomeris together with European genera currently placed in different
   families, Glomeridella and Trachysphaera, as outgroups. Distance,
   maximum parsimony and maximum likelihood methods were employed. Maximum
   parsimony and likelihood analyses did not lead to a well-resolved
   phylogeny, but found a weakly supported sister-group relationship
   between Nearctomeris and Onomeris. All five analyzed pill millipede
   genera differ greatly in their uncorrected basepairs (15[long dash]22%),
   and moderately in their amino acids (5[long dash]10%). As in Onomeris,
   the closest relative of Nearctomeris can probably be found among the
   Asian genera Hyleoglomeris Verhoeff, 1910 or Hyperglomeris Silvestri,
   1917. In America, more attention should be given to the search for other
   small-bodied, cryptic, rare Glomerida.
C1 Wesener, Thomas; Forschungsmuseum Koenig, Adenaueralle 160, 53113 Bonn,
   Germany, Germany.
EM thomas.wesener@rub.de
SC Zoology; Biochemistry &Molecular Biology; Genetics &Heredity;
   Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Biochemistry;
   Genetics; Evolution; Variation; Land zones; Nearctic region; Neotropical
   region; North America; USA; Central America
DE Glomerida [Cytochromes /  / systematics] [Molecular genetics / mtDNA
   variation / ] [Biochemical variation /  / ] [Mexico /  / Key to genera]
   [ /  / distribution] [USA /  / ] [ /  / ] [Guatemala /  / ] [ /  / ]. 
   Nearctomeris inexpectata [Alabama /  / New species] [North Carolina /  /
   ] [Tennessee /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Invertebrates; Myriapods
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Myriapoda, Diplopoda
OR Glomerida (Diplopoda): [Key to genera, Guatemala, Mexico & USA, P. 62]. 
   Nearctomeris (Diplopoda): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Glomerinae, Type
   species Nearctomeris inexpectata, p. 62]. 
   Nearctomeris inexpectata (Diplopoda): [Sp nov, Alabama, P. 63].

DT Article
TI Review of the Lake Malawi genus Melanochromis (Teleostei: Cichlidae)
   with a description of a new species.
AU Konings, Adrianus F. (info@cichlidpress.com) 
   Stauffer, Jay R., Jr
SO Zootaxa
VL 3258
PS 1-27
PD 5 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3258.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/f/zt03258p027.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB The Lake Malawi genus Melanochromis included five species at its
   inception and was originally distinguished from Pseudotropheus on the
   basis of morphology, including the arrangement of teeth on the lower
   pharyngeal bone. The diagnosis has been extended twice, first to include
   all elongate mbuna that possess horizontal stripes and U-shaped tooth
   bands and later to exclude mbuna that do not exhibit a sex-related
   reversal in their colour pattern. Recently, the diagnosis of the genus
   was refined on the basis of the melanin pattern. The genus now includes
   only species with a basic melanin pattern, which consists of two black
   horizontal lateral stripes on a light background. Most adult members of
   the genus, thus defined, have a sex-related reversal of pigmentation
   pattern. Here we describe Melanochromis mpoto n. sp. from the
   northwestern part of Lake Malawi, synonymize M. parallelus
   Burgess&Axelrod 1976 with M. loriae Johnson 1975, redescribe M. chipokae
   Johnson 1975 and M. robustus Johnson 1985, and reclassify and designate
   a lectotype for M. brevis Trewavas, 1935.
C1 Konings, Adrianus F.; Cichlid Press, PO Box 13608, El Paso, TX 79913,
   USA, USA.
EM info@cichlidpress.com

OI Stauffer, Jay/0000-0001-9653-942X

   position, P. 25]. 
   Melanochromis - Trewavas 1935 (Cichlidae): [Key to species, P. 25]. 
   Melanochromis brevis - Trewavas 1935 (Cichlidae): [Lectotype designated,
   P. 22; Referred to, Pseudotropheus, p. 22]. 
   Melanochromis chipokae - Johnson 1975 (Cichlidae): [Redescription, P.
   11]. 
   Melanochromis loriae - Johnson 1975 (Cichlidae): [Redescription, P. 8;

DT Article
TI Redescription of Notomastus hemipodus Hartman, 1945 and N. tenuis Moore,
   1909 (Polychaeta: Capitellidae).
AU Garcia-Garza, M.E.
   Harris, L.H.
   de Leon-Gonzalez, J.A. (jesus.deleongn@uanl.edu.mx) 
SO Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington
VL 125
IS 1
PS 1-11
PD Apr 4 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 10
AB Redescriptions of Notomastus hemipodus and N. tenuis are provided based
   on the examination of type specimens and supplemental material. Details
   of important morphological characters such as epithelial texture,
   lateral organs, genital pores, shape of the hooded hooks, and methyl
   green stain pattern are provided for both species. The two species,
   widely reported along the east, west, and Gulf coasts of North America,
   the Caribbean, and even Nigeria, have been confused since the 1960s.
   Notomastus americanus is newly synonymized with N. hemipodus due to the
   similarity in the characters of epithelial texture, first uniramous
   chaetiger, presence of an anterior palpode, and hooded hooks as well as
   identical methyl green stain patterns.
C1 de Leon-Gonzalez, J.A.; Univ Autonoma Nuevo Leon, Fac Ciencias Biol, AP
   5 F, San Nicolas De Los Garza, Nuevo Leon, Mexico, Mexico.

TI Two new species of Potamothrix (Oligochaeta: Tubificinae) from plateau
   lakes of Yunnan Province, southwest China.
AU Cui, Yongde
   Wang, Hongzhu (wanghz@ihb.ac.cn) 
SO Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington
VL 125
IS 1
PS 12-17
PD Apr 4 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Two new species of Potamothrix (Oligochaeta: Tubificinae), P.
   rhytipeniatus, new species and P. aductus, new species, are described
   from Fuxian Lake and Xingyun Lake of Yunnan Province, southwest China.
   Potamothrix rhytipeniatus differs from congeners by its wrinkled penis
   surface and vasa deferentia entering the atrium subapically. Potamothrix
   aductus is distinguishable from all congeners by lacking a spermathecal
   duct. Hitherto, 31 species of freshwater oligochaetes have been recorded
   from Yunnan Province, including seven endemic species from plateau
   lakes.

DT Article
TI Bathyal gastropods of Bimini Chain, Bahamas.
AU Oleinik, Anton E. (aoleinik@fau.edu) 
   Petuch, Edward J.
   Aley, William C.
SO Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington
VL 125
IS 1
PS 19-53
PD Apr 4 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB This paper summarizes the taxonomic findings of the three cruises on
   board of Florida Institute of Oceanography research vessels Bellows and
   Suncoaster conducted between 2000 and 2005 as well as to discuss the
   unique regional oceanographic settings that were found to be essential
   in supporting the diverse and unique bathyal molluscan fauna encountered
   in the depths of the eastern Straits of Florida. Approximately 30
   stations were sampled, from South Cat Cay (25[degree]42.085'N) through
   Victory Cay (25[degree]28.355'N), at depths ranging from 120-600 meters
   and averaging 400 m depth. A total of 74 molluscan taxa belonging to 34
   families were identified from over 400 individual mollusk specimens. The
   gastropods Architectonica sunderlandi Petuch 1987, Bursa finlayi McGinty
   1962, and Exilia meekiana (Dall, 1889a) were collected from the eastern
   side of the Straits of Florida for the first time. The Ranellid
   Pisanianura grimaldii (Dautzenberg, 1889) is reported from the western
   Atlantic Ocean for the first time. Two new taxa are described, including
   a new species of eratoid, Hespererato pallida, new species, and a new
   species of volute, Scaphella (Scaphella) biminiensis, new species.
   Additionally, a number of rare or otherwise poorly known molluscan taxa
   are illustrated, described, and discussed in context of the
   oceanographic settings from which they were collected. The presence of a
   diverse and unique deep-water molluscan community is attributed to the
   distinctive current structure and temperature asymmetry that has been
   observed between the western and eastern slopes of the Straits of
   Florida.
C1 Oleinik, Anton E.; Florida Atlantic Univ, Dept Geosci, 777 Glades Rd,
   Boca Raton, FL 33631, USA, USA.
EM aoleinik@fau.edu
SC Marine &Freshwater Biology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 0006-324X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Habitat; Marine zones; Atlantic
   Ocean; North Atlantic

   [Caribbean Sea / Bahamas, Bimini Islands / ]. 
   Hespererato pallida; Scaphella (Scaphella) biminiensis [Caribbean Sea /
   Bahamas / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Prosobranchia, Mesogastropoda,
   Cypraeoidea, Neogastropoda, Muricoidea
OR Gastropoda (Mollusca). 
   Hespererato pallida (Cypraeoidea): [Sp nov, Bahamas (marine), P. 26]. 
   Scaphella (Scaphella) biminiensis (Muricoidea): [Sp nov, Bahamas
   (marine), P. 39].

DT Article
TI A new water bear, Minibiotus julianae, from the Caribbean Island of
   Dominica (Tardigrada: Eutardigrada: Parachela: Macrobiotidae).
AU Meyer, Harry A. (hmeyer@mcneese.edu) 
SO Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington
VL 125
IS 1
PS 54-60
PD Apr 4 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 10
AB A new species of tardigrade, Minibiotus acadianus, is described from a
   moss sample collected in June 2009 from a rainforest palm tree on the
   island of Dominica, West Indies. The new species has a buccal tube with
   a single anterior curvature, two macroplacoids, and a microplacoid. The
   cuticle is smooth with small, evenly-distributed circular or elliptical
   pores. Eggs have a reticulated shell surface and short inverted goblet
   egg process; a dentate margin on the distal dish of the processes bears
   10-12 short teeth. The new species is most similar to Minibiotus
   acadianus Meyer&Domingue, 2011; both have wider buccal tubes than other
   species in the genus. The new species is easily distinguished from M.
   acadianus in lacking cuticular gibbosities and in some characters of the
   egg.
C1 Meyer, Harry A.; McNeese State Univ, Dept Biol & Hlth Sci, Lake Charles,
   LA 70609, USA, USA.
EM hmeyer@mcneese.edu
SC Zoology
SN 0006-324X

   Central America; West Indies

ST Animalia, Tardigrada

DT Article
TI Rogadius fehlmanni, a new flathead fish (Scorpaeniformes:
   Platycephalidae) from Somalia.
AU Knapp, Leslie W. (knappl@si.edu) 
SO Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington
VL 125
IS 1
PS 61-65
PD Apr 4 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Three species of Rogadius Jordan&Richardson, 1908, with antrorse
   preopercular spines have been previously known from the western Indian
   Ocean (WIO). A new species, Rogadius fehlmanni, is described from eight
   specimens taken at three localities off Somalia. It is distinguished
   from its congeners by the following combination of characters: lower
   edge of preopercle developed as a stout antrorse spine; preocular spines
   2-4, usually with accessory spines on base of the largest; 5-6 diagonal
   scale rows between second dorsal fin and lateral line; pelvic fins
   blackish, lacking individual dark spots. A key separating the four
   species is provided.
C1 Knapp, Leslie W.; Smithsonian Inst, Natl Museum Nat Hist, POB 37012,
   Washington, DC 20013, USA, USA.

   Ocean

DT Article
TI A new species of treeskink (Squamata: Scincidae: Emoia samoensis species
   group) from Rotuma, south-central Pacific.
AU Zug, George R. (zugg@si.edu) 
SO Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington
VL 125
IS 1
PS 74-84
PD Apr 4 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Rotuma, the northern-most Fijian island, reportedly has two resident
   species of treeskinks of the Emoia samoensis species group. One species
   is a member of the Emoia concolor species subgroup and was last reported
   from Rotuma in the 1890s. The other species is a member of the Emoia
   samoensis subgroup. Members of the latter subgroup are robust-bodied
   skinks in contrast to the more slender-bodied concolor. The abundant
   treeskink on Rotuma is more slender-bodied than other samoensis subgroup
   members but clearly belongs to this subgroup. It possesses other
   differences, particularly in scalation, that demonstrate its
   differentiation and speciation in the remote and isolated Rotuma
   Islands. It is recognized herein as a new species Emoia oriva. A key to
   the members of the Emoia samoensis species group provides a current
   summary of phenetic relationships in this group although on-going
   studies suggest at least a half-dozen species remain undescribed in the
   samoensis species group.
C1 Zug, George R.; Smithsonian Inst, Natl Museum Nat Hist, POB 37012,
   Washington, DC 20013, USA, USA.
EM zugg@si.edu
SC Zoology
SN 0006-324X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones; Oceanic
   islands; Pacific Ocean islands

   Sauria, Scincidae
OR Emoia oriva (Scincidae): [Sp nov, Fiji, P. 75]. 
   Emoia samoensis species group (Scincidae): [Key to species, P. 82].

TI A new species of towhee (Aves: Emberizidae: Pipilo) from Quaternary
   deposits on Bermuda.
AU Olson, Storrs L. (olsons@si.edu) 
   Wingate, David B.
SO Proceedings of the Biological Society of Washington
VL 125
IS 1
PS 85-96
PD Apr 4 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB Pipilo naufragus, new species, is described from Middle and Late
   Pleistocene to Holocene cave and pond deposits on the island of Bermuda.
   It is most similar to the Eastern Towhee P. erythrophthalmus but differs
   in having a heavier bill, more robust hindlimbs, and reduced wing and
   pectoral girdle, with the sternum in particular being shorter, wider,
   and with a much smaller carina. At least one early historical account
   (1610) contains a description of a large bunting-like bird that almost
   certainly refers to this species, which would have been exterminated by
   introduced pigs, rats, and cats following human settlement of Bermuda in
   1612.
C1 Olson, Storrs L.; Smithsonian Inst, Dept Vertebrate Zool, POB 30712,
   Washington, DC 20013, USA, USA.
EM olsons@si.edu

   Atlantic Ocean islands; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Quaternary

   [Pleistocene /  / ].

TI A new cryptic species of glassfrog (Centrolenidae: Nymphargus) from
   Reserva Las Gralarias, Ecuador.
AU Hutter, Carl R. (carl.hutter@gmail.com) 
   Guayasamin, Juan M.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3257
PS 1-21
PD 4 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3257.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03257p021.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB We describe a new species of Nymphargus from Reserva Las Gralarias, in
   the montane forests of the Pacific versant of the Andes of Ecuador. The
   new species, Nymphargus lasgralarias sp. nov., is nearly morphologically
   identical to sympatric Nymphargus griffithsi (Goin 1961), with the
   exception of the following characters: (i) a gold colored iris with
   numerous small spots and lighter reticulation, (ii) absence of dark
   dorsal spotting, and (iii) a significantly larger body size.
   Additionally, we describe the vocalizations for N. griffithsi and N.
   lasgralarias. The call of N. lasgralarias sp. nov. is easily
   distinguished from N. griffithsi through the following temporal and
   spectral characteristics: (i) calls are emitted in series, (ii) waveform
   shape is always pulsed, (iii) significantly shorter call duration, and
   (iv) lower dominant frequency.
C1 Hutter, Carl R.; Department of Ecology and Evolution, Stony Brook
   University, Stony Brook, NY 11794-5245, USA, USA.
EM carl.hutter@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   South America

   Centrolenidae
OR Nymphargus lasgralarias (Centrolenidae): [Sp nov, Ecuador, P. 5].

DT Article
TI On some shallow-water Tanaidomorpha (Crustacea: Peracarida: Tanaidacea)
   of Chilean fjords, with description of a new species of Zeuxoides Sieg,
   1980.
AU Esquete, Patricia (pesquete@uvigo.es) 
   Bamber, Roger
   Aldea, Cristian
SO Zootaxa
VL 3257
PS 38-55
PD 4 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3257.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/f/zt03257p055.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Magellanic tanaidacean faunas have been mainly studied in the Magellan
   Strait and Beagle Channel, the latter restricted to bottoms deeper than
   40m. As a result, the shallow rocky bottoms of the Magellanic fjords
   remain largely under-studied, and their tanaidacean diversity is poorly
   known. In this study, tanaidacean species sampled from shallow rocky
   bottoms of Chilean fjords are investigated, and morphological and
   taxonomic considerations included. A new species of the Tanaidae,
   Zeuxoides troncosoi sp. nov. is described. The genus Leptochelia is
   recorded for the first time in Chile, and the distribution of
   Pancoloides litoralis is extended northwards. Specimens collected of
   Pancoloides litoralis and Nototanais dimorphus present morphological
   differences with previous descriptions, which are at present attributed
   to intraspecific variation derived from geographical isolation among
   populations, until sufficient material can be examined to determine what
   constitutes interspecific and intraspecific variation.
C1 Esquete, Patricia; Departamento de Ecologia & Biologia Animal, Facultad
   de Ciencias del Mar, Universidad de Vigo, E-36310 Vigo, Pontevedra,
   Spain, Spain.
EM pesquete@uvigo.es
RI Esquete, Patricia/E-8881-2015
OI Esquete, Patricia/0000-0002-9595-1524
SC Zoology; Marine &Freshwater Biology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Habitat; Marine zones; Pacific
   Ocean
DE Leptochelia [South Pacific / Chile / New record; systematics]. 
   Nototanais dimorphus; Pancoloides cf. litoralis [South Pacific / Chile /
   Distribution; systematics]. 
   Tanaidomorpha [Marine habitat / Fjord / Distribution; systematics;
   shallow-water taxa] [South Pacific / Chile / ]. 
   Zeuxoides troncosoi [South Pacific / Chile / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca,
   Peracarida, Tanaidacea
OR Leptochelia - Dana 1849 (Tanaidacea): [New record]. 
   Nototanais dimorphus - (Beddard 1886) (Tanaidacea). 
   Pancoloides cf. litoralis - (Vanhoeffen 1914) (Tanaidacea). 
   Tanaidomorpha (Tanaidacea). 
   Zeuxoides troncosoi - Esquete & Bamber 2012 (Tanaidacea): [Sp nov, Chile
   (marine), P. 39].

AN ZOOR14805040618
DT Article
TI Soares testudinarius gen. et sp. nov. (Hemiptera: Fulgoromorpha:
   Flatidae), a new representative of the tribe Phantiini from Madagascar.
AU Stroinski, Adam (adam@miiz.waw.pl) 
   Swierczewski, Dariusz
SO Zootaxa
VL 3256
PS 38-50
PD 4 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3256.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03256p050.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This paper describes a new flatid genus, Soares gen. nov., and a new
   species S. testudinarius sp. nov. from Madagascar. The new genus is
   assigned to the tribe Phantiini (subfamily Flatinae), which is recorded
   from Madagascar for the first time. Additionally, the illustrations of
   the female internal genital structures are provided.
C1 Stroinski, Adam; Museum and Institute of Zoology, Polish Academy of
   Sciences, ul. Wilcza 64, 00-697 Warszawa, Poland, Poland.
EM adam@miiz.waw.pl
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   Africa

   Soares testudinarius [Madagascar /  / New species].

   Fulgoroidea, Flatidae

   Soares (Flatidae): [Gen nov, Of tribe Phantiini, Type species Soares
   testudinarius, p. 39]. 
   Soares testudinarius (Flatidae): [Sp nov, Madagascar, P. 49].

DT Article
TI Two new species of Fibuloides Kuznetsov, 1997 (Lepidoptera: Tortricidae)
   from Thailand.
AU Pinkaew, Nantasak (agrnsp@ku.ac.th) 
   Zhang, Aihuan
SO Zootaxa
VL 3256
PS 51-57
PD 4 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3256.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/f/zt03256p057.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of Fibuloides Kuznetsov, 1997, F. geniculata Pinkaew and
   Zhang, n. sp., and F. khaoyai Pinkaew and Zhang, n. sp., are described
   and illustrated from Thailand. The two new species bring to 11 the
   number of Fibuloides documented from Thailand.

AN ZOOR14805040620
DT Article
TI A new species of the genus Spiritiops Lugo-Ortiz & McCafferty
   (Ephemeroptera, Baetidae) from the Pantepui biogeographical province.
AU Nieto, Carolina (macarolina_nieto@yahoo.com.ar) 
   Derka, Tomas
SO Zootaxa
VL 3256
PS 58-63
PD 4 Apr 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3256.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03256p063.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Spiritiops was described by Lugo-Ortiz&McCafferty in 1998.
   Since then, only the type species, S. silvudus, was reported from
   different countries, such as Brazil, French Guiana, Surinam and
   Venezuela. In the last years, various international speleological
   expedition explored summits of some table mountains called tepuis in
   Guyana region in south-eastern Venezuela. Here we describe a new species
   of the genus Spiritiops, found at three tepuis (Auyan-tepui, Churi-tepui
   and Mt. Roraima) during above mentioned speleological expeditions.
C1 Nieto, Carolina; CONICET-Instituto de Biodiversidad Neotropical,
   Facultad de Ciencias Naturales e IML, Miguel Lillo 251, Tucuman, UNASUR
   (4000), Argentina, Argentina.
EM macarolina_nieto@yahoo.com.ar
OI Nieto, Carolina/0000-0003-1909-1750
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; South America

TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates

   species, Nymphs, p. 60]. 
   Spiritiops tepuiensis (Ephemeroptera): [Sp nov, Venezuela, P. 60].
